Content:
In a world governed by strategic interests and geographical policies, US President Donald Trump has sparked widespread controversy with his plan to displace 2.2 million Palestinians from the Gaza Strip to Egypt and Jordan.
This plan, which was justified in phrases such as "cleansing" of Gaza from its residents after a 15 -month destroyer, faces major legal and international obstacles, inspired by historical strategies that had previously failed to achieve its goals.
In this article, we review the legal dimensions of this controversial plan, and shed light on historical attempts of forced displacement, and we discuss the mechanisms through which Egypt and Jordan can, along with the international community, address these plans, with a focus on promoting the steadfastness of the Palestinians as a strategic option that preserves their rights And their national identity.
The statements of US President Donald Trump regarding a plan to deport Palestinians from Gaza to Egypt and Jordan in a complex international context characterized by escalating tensions in the Middle East, where Gaza witnessed repeated Israeli wars that led to the deterioration of humanitarian conditions.
These statements were associated with the plan of the "Deal of the Century" launched by Trump as part of a political settlement aimed at strengthening the interests of Israel by providing promises Economic for the Palestinians without meeting their legitimate political rights, which was widely rejected.
It also coincided with the Trump administration pushing towards signing normalization agreements between Israel and a number of Arab countries (Abraham Conventions), which contributed to reducing pressure on Israel towards the Palestinian issue. Internationally, the plan came in light of American tensions with Iran, which supports the Palestinian armed factions in Gaza, with the aim of weakening Iranian influence in the region.
Internally, Trump was seeking to enhance his popularity in his pro -Israel base, especially evangelical Christians, in the context of preparing for the elections, while exerting pressure on Egypt and Jordan to assume additional responsibilities towards Palestinian refugees, in a way that reduces Israel any political, economic or security burdens.
History has witnessed multiple attempts to deport the Palestinians or resettle them outside their homeland, all of which have failed to achieve their goals due to political complications and popular resistance.
Among the most prominent of these attempts is the settlement project in Sinai in 1955, which was proposed by Israel with British and American support to resettle Palestinian refugees in North Sinai, but it faced a firm Egyptian rejection led by Gamal Abdel Nasser and an opposition Stead Palestinian.
Attempts to settle the Palestinians in Jordan also emerged during the 1960s and 1970s, which caused the escalation of tension between the Palestinian factions and the Jordanian regime, and ended with the events of September in 1970.
Likewise, the United Nations and Western countries have put forward plans such as international resettlement programs via "UNRWA", which called for the resettlement of the Palestinians in host countries in exchange for financial support, but they met a decisive rejection of Palestinian refugees who adhered to the right to return, and the Arab countries that were afraid of liquidating the Palestinian cause or Polishing political balance. The reasons for the failure of these attempts are due to the Palestinian adherence to his national rights, and the Arab countries refused to hold them responsible for resolving the issue on behalf of Israel.
For decades, Israel has sought to displace the Palestinians, especially in the Gaza Strip, using security and military excuses to evacuate residential areas and create a demographic change that serves its strategic interests. These attempts began early, but they appeared clearly during a military operation called the steadfast shelf in 2014, as the occupation army targeted the northern Gaza Strip, such as Beit Hanoun and Beit Lahia, with intense bombing, with warnings to the residents to evacuate Their homes. Despite a temporary displacement of some families to shelter centers, most of the population returned upon the end of the fighting, which led to the failure of Israel's attempt to make a permanent demographic change.
In subsequent years, the Israeli targets became more clear through the statements of prominent officials, confirming the endeavor to displace or liquidate Palestinians. For example, the Israeli National Security Minister, Etamar bin Ghaffir, called for "resettlement of hundreds of thousands of Gaza population", while the Minister of Finance in Salail Smotrich supported measures aimed at a demographic change in the Strip. These statements sparked widespread international condemnation and described as evidence of Israeli intentions to make a fundamental change in the demographic Gaza composition.
During the last war on Gaza in 2023, Israeli attempts to achieve these goals escalated. Israel also explicitly announced its aim to evacuate the northern Gaza Strip by allegedly eliminating the resistance tunnels and the Hamas infrastructure. As Israel resorted to the use of intense bombing and mass warning to force the population to go to the south.
Despite the severity of the bombing and the targeting of large areas such as Jabalia, Beit Lahia and Beit Hanoun, as well as health infrastructure Especially Kamal Adwan Hospital, the Palestinians resisted these pressures, considering that the evacuation paves the process of permanent forced displacement. With the ends of the operations, the residents gradually returned to their homes, showing Israel's failure to impose a permanent demographic change.
In this context, the Israeli historian Beni Morris highlights in his writings, such as "1948 and then" and "Nakba: The story of the Arab-Israeli conflict", that the Israeli policies towards the Palestinians have always included the element of forced displacement as part of a strategic plan.
Morris notes that the Palestinian displacement during the Nakba in 1948 was not merely a result of the war, but rather was part of a deliberate policy of ethnic cleansing with the aim of reducing the number of Arab population within the occupied territories. It also confirms that subsequent attempts, including the major wars such as the steadfast shelf and the war on Gaza in 2023, were aimed at achieving Israeli demographic hegemony, but failed due to Palestinian steadfastness and international pressure.
In addition to the military operations, an investigation of Amnesty International indicated that Israel is committing acts that amount to genocide, including deliberate killing and physical and psychological harm to the population, in addition to being subjected to them For harsh living conditions aimed at destroying them. These policies reflect a clear Israeli attempt to liquidate the Palestinian presence in Gaza through a mixture of displacement and genocide.
Israel's attempts to deport the Palestinians, despite its fierceness and continuous escalation, revealed a permanent deficit in achieving its goals. This is due to the steadfastness of the Palestinians and their insistence on adhering to their land.
International law categorically rejects forced displacement, based on major texts condemning these practices in times of war and peace. The Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 stipulates in Article 49 the ban on the forced transportation of the population from the occupied lands, and Article 147 describes forced displacement as a serious violation and war crime.
The statute of the International Criminal Court (Rome 1998) also strengthens this position, where Article 8 (2) (B) (8) (8) criminalizes illegal displacement, while Article 7 (1) (d) is forced displacement a crime against humanity if it is widely done. Domain or methodology.
In addition, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights stresses the right of individuals to freedom of movement and choose their place By force and ensuring the right of Palestinian refugees to return.
The displacement of the Palestinians is not only a flagrant violation of international law, but also means liquidating the Palestinian cause and burying the aspirations of the Palestinian people in building their state.
How can we talk about a Palestinian state without a people on the ground? Whether in the West Bank, the Gaza Strip, or Jerusalem, the displacement aims to uproot the Palestinian people from its historical roots and turn the land into a fully Israeli settlement project, which makes any path towards a two -state solution impossible.
International laws provide a strong framework for the condemnation of forced displacement, as their texts are a reference to impose political and diplomatic pressure on Israel through international organizations such as the United Nations and the International Criminal Court.
However, the application of this law faces great challenges; The absence of effective implementation mechanisms depends heavily on the cooperation of states, which makes the implementation of rulings difficult in the event that the accused parties refuse to commit.
In addition, there is duplication of international standards where the major powers such as the United States protect Israel from international sanctions, as is documented in many decisions that have been withheld in Security Council.
The current geopolitical environment places barriers to a sufficient international consensus to impose sanctions, as happened in the United Nations General Assembly, where some countries refused to recognize displacement as a crime. To achieve actual success, international political will must be strengthened, increased popular and legal pressure, and the exploitation of legal platforms to raise coherent issues that expose these practices and put Israel under international accountability. Without this, international law will remain a powerful tool on paper, but it is in reality.
Both Egypt and Jordan oppose any attempts to forced displacement of the Palestinians as a flagrant violation of international law, especially the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949, which prohibits the forced transport of the population, and the statute of the International Criminal Court that classifies forced displacement as a crime of war and a crime against humanity. It also contradicts the axioms of Arab national security and its title to support the Palestinian issue.
The two countries previously rejected similar plans because of its direct impact on internal stability in them, in addition to the failure of Israel or its Western allies to bring political solutions acceptable.
Egypt and Jordan's official and diplomatic positions With clear statements, it increases international pressure on Israel and exposes it to wide criticism, which supports the steadfastness of the Palestinians on their land and prevents the granting of any political cover for attempts to displace.
In practice, Egypt and Jordan can take studied steps to prevent the implementation of any forced displacement plans. The border monitoring must be strengthened to ensure that the Palestinians are not forcibly displaced, while ensuring a safe and sustainable flow of humanitarian aid to Gaza to alleviate the economic and humanitarian pressures that may push the population to displace.
In this context, Egypt, in particular, should face Israeli and American pressure that may hinder the entry of aid or the transit of individuals for humanitarian purposes.
The two countries also have to support Palestinians within the sector through cooperation with international organizations, while activating regional and international coordination through the League of Arab States and the Organization of Islamic Cooperation to mobilize a unified Arab position that enhances Israel's isolation on the international scene.
These efforts prevent any demographic changes in Gaza and keep the Palestinian issue in the circle of international attention, while emphasizing the right of the Palestinians to return.

The document developed a general plan to re -occupy the Gaza Strip, starting with displacement Its population is from north to south, and in the meantime a gradual cleansing campaign for Hamas and its tunnels begins; In order to ultimately transfer the population from the Gaza Strip to northern Sinai.
And it is possible to look at the patterns taken by the Israeli war on Gaza, exploring that it was already guided by this plan, which if it opposed it public statements by the US Secretary of State at the time, Anthony Blinkin, then the merely out of these statements is a disclosure of deliberations that were taking place in a serious manner in the scenes The administration of the war on Gaza.
Plinken's public statements that reject the displacement were coming in the midst of leaks that talk about his pressure personally on a number of Arab countries to receive the residents of the Gaza Strip after their displacement, which in turn reflected in Arab statements that show real concern about serious pressures on Arab countries to accept receiving the residents of the Gaza Strip The most prominent of which was the statement of Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El -Sisi at a press conference that he collected with German Chancellor Olaf Schultz on October 18, 2023, in which he said: "If there is an idea for displacement, the Negev desert is in Israel, the Palestinians can be displaced to it until Israel has finished its declared mission to liquidate Resistance, or armed groups: Hamas, Islamic jihad, and others, then return them if it wants, but Egypt cannot bear the consequences of the transfer of residents of the Gaza Strip to it in a loose military operation that may last for years, which would turn Sinai into a base for the resistance, and end peace between Egypt and Israel.

Trump's comments not only reveal the real American position regarding the Israeli war and its final goals, but also reveals the failure of the Israeli war to accomplish this goal at the time specified by an American, the American frustration appeared in the length of this war quickly, as in statements to Anthony Blink in December 2023 He said in it: "If the enthusiasm handed its weapons, the war will end immediately."

So I prefer to cooperate with some Arab countries and build housing elsewhere, perhaps there they can live in peace. "
These statements explain the goals of the systematic Israeli destruction of the Gaza Strip. Direct goals are:

This is what reminds of previous statements by the Israeli Finance Minister, the leader of the Religious Zionism Party, in Salail Smotrich, in which he said: “Encouraging voluntary immigration is the possibility of opening up, and it is possible to create a situation that makes Gaza in half of its current population within two years, with full control of a state Israel.
What Trump finally said is identical to what Smotrich said, Trump talks about the displacement of half of the population of the Gaza Strip, and he invokes The situation created by the Israeli war to justify it.
What should be emphasized is that the displacement plans for the residents of the Gaza Strip are constantly raised within the Israeli establishment since 1967 by Moshe Dayan, and in the Eagal Alon plan.

American statements were met with a unified position, by Jordan, Egypt, the Palestinian Authority and the Palestinian factions, which is completely the refusal of the displacement.
The next day, large numbers of displaced people returned on foot, carrying bags or vehicles, to the coastal road towards the northern Gaza Strip areas from which they were displaced during the war.

Political analyst Sharhabeel Al -Gharib, who inhabits the Gaza Strip, assured the BBC, that there is a popular rejection in the Gaza Strip, and a state of ridicule of statements.
The stranger explained that the Palestinian position is based on three pillars, which are the popular level, the level of the factions, and the official level (the Palestinian Authority).
He said that these combined pillars refuse and say, "No to reproduce the deal of the century," adding that "the Palestinian people are the owner of the land. It cannot be accepted to be abandoned from its land."
The stranger considered that "forced displacement" is merely an illusion, and it failed during the war in front of the Palestinians' adherence to their land, as they were displaced from the north of Gaza to the south, and they refused to come out towards the Egyptian border.
The stranger said that Israel paved the displacement by "killing all forms of life in the Gaza Strip."
Al -Ghariba considered in an interview with the BBC that Trump's statements lack a real vision and plan, and he said that The US President is trying to reproduce the deal of the century and impose it on the region.
The administration of former US President Joe Biden has thought about the idea of ??transferring some of the population temporarily in the early war, but Jordan and Egypt insisted on their rejection that Washington quickly abandoned the idea, according to the newspaper "Times of Israel".
In 1948, more than 760,000 Palestinians were displaced and expelled during the war that erupted during the establishment of the State of Israel.
About 80 percent of Gaza residents are refugees, children and grandchildren of refugees who left their homes during "Nakba" in 1948.
There are more than six million Palestinian refugees in the region registered with UNRWA.
During the 1967 war during which Israel occupied the Gaza Strip and the West Bank, more displacement occurred.

Regarding the ability to resist Trump's pressure, Qamhawi said that Jordan is a poor country and put it weaker than Egypt, but the position of the Jordanian people on the issue of displacement is clear and decisive, and they cannot accept this, even if the government accepts.
He added: "I do not think that a country like Egypt lacks the ingredients that enable it to take independent positions, and it can withstand any American political pressure."

The statement said that Cairo "rejects any A prejudice to those unusable rights, whether through settlement or the inclusion of the land or by evacuating that land from their owners through displacement or encouraging transportation or uprooting Palestinians from their land, whether it is temporary or long -term.
And previously, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El -Sisi warned that the displacement would be aimed at "liquidating the Palestinian issue."
During the first month of the war, the Egyptian President said that Israel could move the residents of the Gaza Strip to the Negev desert until the end of the war in Gaza, and rejected the idea of ??displacement to the Egyptian Sinai Peninsula.
A spokesman for the League of Arab States, Jamal Rushdi, told the BBC that attempts to displace the Palestinians, or remove the Palestinian people, whether through displacement or what is known as the scenarios of the annexation, or even the expansion of settlements, adequately rejected ideas and attempts, because they are contrary to international law.
After Trump announced on Sunday, his intention to contact Sisi, an official Egyptian source denied conducting contact regarding the issue of resettlement of the Palestinians in Egypt and Jordan.

The Sphinx saw that the deportation plan for Egypt and Jordan is unrealistic and unrealistic, and any deportation will turn into permanent displacement.
He referred to Cairo's warning of an Israeli plan for displacement, and said that Egypt had previously hinted that it would prevent the displacement, even by force.
The Sphinx said that Cairo had received financial offers and temptations for displacement, but it rejects a form and content.
Political analyst Sharhabeel Al -Gharib saw that Jordan and Egypt's positions on the issue of deportation are "very important", and he saw that Trump's statements "may be maneuvers to explore Jordanian and Egyptian positions."
It is strange that the implementation of the Trump plan is subject to Jordan and Egypt's positions after the position of the Palestinian people.
Al -Gharib called on BBC, Egypt to take steps to enhance the steadfastness of the Palestinian people in their land.
Al -Gharib spoke about the necessity of steadfast these positions in front of economic pressures and American material temptations.

For the second time in a week, US President Donald Trump renews his statements about the acceptance of Jordan and Egypt to receive the people of Gaza, after a proposal submitted by Saturday, January 25, 2025 for "clearing" the sector, which he said has become a "devastating place".

Jordan had responded to the first statements of the American president to reject, stressing the words of his foreign minister, Ayman Al -Safadi, that "Oman holds a two -state solution, a single way to achieve security, stability and peace in the region."
As for Egypt, President Abdel Fattah El -Sisi said, "The transfer of the Palestinian people from its place is an injustice that we cannot participate in," and he saw that in this step "the instability of Egyptian national security and Arab national security in our region."

Six Arab countries confirmed during a meeting held in Cairo on the first of February, their rejection of theses and projects aimed at "displacing the Palestinians" outside their lands and under any circumstance.
The meeting of the foreign ministers of Egypt, Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, the State of Qatar, the Secretary of the Executive Committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and the Secretary -General of the League of Arab States, in response to the invitation of US President Donald Trump to displace the population of the Palestinian Gaza Strip to Egypt, And Jordan.
In a clear message from the six Arab countries, the declared statement at the conclusion of the Cairo administration’s meeting urged the Trump administration to seek to achieve the final solution to the Palestinian issue and the Arab -Israeli conflict according to the principle of the “two -state solution” through which permanent and fair peace in the Middle East can be achieved.
The topic of the call to "displace the Palestinians" is not new in the record of the struggle that extends for more than seven decades between the Arab-Palestinian and Israel side; Which occupies all Palestinian territories, the Golan Heights, Jabal Al -Sheikh, and many other regions of Syria.
Since 1948 and attempts to displace Palestinians from their lands, both by a state The occupation, or by other continuous countries, and each stage of the conflict was targeting the Palestinian presence on its soil, and was framework for facades that created the means of international and regional presence in the media and political; Sometimes the requests for displacement are security or political motives, or others, and always the Palestinian, Arab and international position was rejection.
Despite Israel's attempts during the 1948 war, about 750,000 Palestinians of their homes were displaced as a result of the military operations of the gangs associated with the Zionist movement at the time, which caused the destruction of hundreds of Palestinian villages and forced its people to displace them, and since that date the issue of Palestinian refugees was a major humanitarian humanitarian problem that the international community rejected, despite pressure Which was practiced by leaders of the Zionist movement at the time because the Palestinian refugees did not return To their homes, the United Nations issued Resolution 194, which affirms the right of Palestinian refugees to return to their homes, which has not yet been implemented.
After the six -day war in 1967, in which Israel occupied the West Bank, Gaza Strip and East Jerusalem, it led to the displacement of about 245,000 Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza Strip to Jordan, and towards 11 thousand from the Gaza Strip to Egypt, and 116 thousand Palestinians and Syrians from the Golan Heights to Syria, as these countries constitute a geographical extension of the aforementioned areas.
In the eighties of the last century, and during the first Palestinian uprising (1987-1993), calls from some Israeli politicians to displace the Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza Strip appeared, one of the most prominent advocates of that Israeli politician Rehavam Zeevi, who proposed the "deportation" of the Palestinians to other Arab countries .
These calls faced widespread criticism from the international community, and were rejected by the Arab countries. Then the Oslo agreements signed on September 13, 1993 came to confirm the necessity of resolving the Palestinian issue through negotiations and not through "displacement".
The Arab Summit in Beirut in 2002 adopted the Arab Peace Initiative, which was presented by the late Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, Abdullah bin Abdulaziz, when he was the crown prince, which guarantees the achievement of peace in the Middle East between Israel and the Palestinians on the basis of the establishment of an internationally recognized Palestinian state on the 1967 borders. And the return of refugees and withdrawing from the occupied Syrian Golan Heights, in exchange for recognition and normalization Relations between all Arab countries with Israel.
The Israeli response to this initiative in the tongue of Ariel Sharon, the then Israeli Prime Minister, was to reject the proposal categorically on the basis that it requires Israel to accept a large number of Palestinian refugees, and that it exceeds the Israeli "red lines".
The issue of forced displacement of the Palestinians from their homes and homeland has extended from 1948 until today; Displacement calls are often issued by Israeli and American politicians.
Although the Palestinian refugees enjoy the right to return to their homes from which they were displaced under Resolution 194 issued by the United Nations General Assembly in 1948, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in 1948, the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949, as well Refugee conditions in 1951, the occupying country completely ignores all of this Its dealings of the Palestinian people, and always seeks to achieve its goal to evacuate the land of Palestine from the Palestinians.
US President Donald Trump, in his first term 2017-2021 What was called the "Deal of the Century", but this was not achieved during his first age.
But the 15 -month war of Gaza put this issue in its priorities for the current presidential period, so he launched its proposal to transfer the Palestinians from Gaza and the occupied West Bank to Egypt and the neighboring Jordan under any circumstance Its accredited all over the world between countries.
This requires the response of Egyptian President Abdel Fattah Al -Sisi and the Jordanian monarch Abdullah bin Al -Hussein, where the Egyptian President said during a joint press conference with his guest, Kenyan President William Roto: "Egypt will not participate in the displacement of the Palestinian people as" historical injustice, and added: "It is not possible to leniency Or allow the displacement of the Palestinians due to its impact on the Egyptian national security and Arab national security, "noting that" what happened since the seventh of October, until Now it is the result of the repercussions of not reaching the solution of the Palestinian issue. "
In turn, Jordan affirmed, through its foreign minister, Ayman Al -Safadi, that "Jordan's position on the displacement of the Palestinians" is not changing and necessary to achieve stability and peace. What we all want.
US President Donald Trump may go to the threat of economic sanctions against the countries that reject its proposal, especially Egypt and Jordan, which suffer from difficult economic conditions, but the strength of the position of allied countries of Washington, led by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, and Turkey, will keep the doors of dialogue and communication open With the White House.
Consequently, the language of interests, if it is better to use, with all international demands supporting the solution of the Arab -Israeli conflict through the portal (two -state solution) can give Trump a better vision to retract his proposal and replace it at the invitation of an international conference to rebuild Gaza.
The positions of the Arab countries rejecting the idea of ??displacing the Palestinians proposed by US President Donald Trump on the displacement of the people of the Gaza Strip to Egypt and Jordan, indicating the unity of this position based on legal, political and academic references, and also confirms that the solution of the Palestinian issue must take place through negotiations, and according to decisions International, while respecting the right of the Palestinians to return and live on their soil, and this position has reached completely clearly to the White House, and to the Prime Minister of the occupation state, Benjamin Netanyahu.
It is also remarkable in the Arab position that some Arab countries that are not printed with Israel offered the establishment of a Palestinian state in exchange for normalization with it, such as Algeria, for example, whose president, Abdul Majeed Taboun, said: His country is ready to normalize its relations with Israel on the day when a full Palestinian state is establishing.
While the chances of normalization between Riyadh and Tel Aviv, which Trump sought in his first term, decreases for not achieving what the Kingdom requested regarding the two -state solution and the return of Palestinian refugees to their homes.
The Arab position is pushing two directions: the first rejects the issue of displacing the Palestinians categorically, and the second is to open the prospects for peace and global and regional peace through the establishment of a Palestinian state over its entire soil with the limits of the six -day war in 1967, and a full Arab normalization with Israel.

Five Arab foreign ministers, in addition to a senior Palestinian official, sent a "common message" to US Secretary of State Marco Rubio, in which they renewed their rejection of plans to displace the Palestinians from Gaza proposed by President Donald Trump at the end of January.
This message was sent on Monday, which is signed by the foreign ministers of Saudi Arabia, the Emirates, Qatar, Egypt and Jordan, as well as the advisor of the Palestinian President Hussein Al -Sheikh.
Axius was the first to report the news, noting that the ministers met in Cairo at the beginning of the week.
On January 25, Trump laid for the first time the reception of Jordan and Egypt from the Gaza Strip. When asked if he was suggested as a long -term or short -term solution, the American president said: "None of them."
His statements have made these ancient Palestinian concerns about their displacement from their homes forever, and criticized them as a proposal for ethnic cleansing. Jordan, Egypt and other Arab countries opposed the proposal.
The letter said: "The reconstruction of Gaza must take place through direct interaction with the people of Gaza and their participation. The Palestinians will live in their land and help rebuild it."
The Arab foreign ministers added: "They should not be removed from their land during the reconstruction, as they should actively participate in the process with the support of the international community."
The ministers had said Saturday in a joint statement during a meeting in Cairo that they refused to "displace" the Palestinians from their land or "encourage their transfer", expressing their hope to work with the Donald Trump administration "in order to implement the two -state solution."
For reference, the statements of the Ministry of Health in Gaza indicated that the Israeli military attack on the Strip killed more than 47,000 Palestinians, and sparked accusations of genocide and war crimes denied by Tel Aviv.
The battles have now stopped with a fragile ceasefire.

Since the Nakba 1948, (Israel) has not stopped seeking to displace the Palestinians from their lands, whether through the war, or through systematic plans sometimes enjoyed American support. Over the course of decades, frequent projects appeared to resettle the Palestinians in neighboring countries, but they did not see the light due to the Palestinian, Arab and official rejection, and the Palestinian clinging to the right to stay on the ground despite all attempts to uproot them.
With the outbreak of the war on Gaza on October 7, 2023, the talk returned again about the displacement, to find its way to the international political scene through new proposals, which were not the first and will not be the last, but it all collided with two main workers: Palestinian steadfastness, and the Arab and international rejection of the idea of ??forced displacement.
History repeats itself
After declaring (Israel) in 1948, the Palestinians were subjected to a major catastrophe, which was displaced hundreds of thousands of their lands. With the increase in the number of refugees, their resettlement proposals began to appear in other Arab countries. In 1953, Washington launched the "Sinai Plan", which included the transfer of Palestinians to Egyptian lands, but it was met with official rejection.
In the 1960s, the role of Israeli Foreign Minister Igal Alon, who suggested deporting the Palestinians To Jordan and Egypt, but his plan was not achieved due to the lack of sufficient international support, in addition to the Arab peoples' rejection of these projects.
Enterprises are not completed
In 1970, Ariel Sharon, the then commander of the southern region of the Israeli army, adopted a plan to evacuate the Gaza Strip from its residents and deport them to Al -Arish in Sinai, but it failed due to political and field complications.
With the advent of the new millennium, talking about "the alternative homeland" returned through plans such as the proposal of the Israeli General Guarara Island in 2000, who called for Egypt's concessions in Sinai in favor of a Palestinian state, but Cairo categorically rejected. In 2004, the idea was repeated through a project presented by Joshua bin Arra, but he did not go into implementation.
In 2018, the most prominent American plan appeared in this context, as part of the "Deal of the Century", which proposed solutions to settle the Palestinians outside their lands, but it met an explicit Arab rejection, especially from Jordan and Egypt.
Gaza War 2023: New displacement attempts
With the intensification of the war on Gaza in October 2023, (Israel) returned to raise the issue of the displacement of the residents of the Gaza Strip, and this time through a "secret document" revealed by the newspaper "Israel Today", which spoke about plans to remove the Palestinians to Egypt. On October 17, 2023, the Israeli "Mjafaf" institute published a research paper calling for the unloading of Gaza from its residents, which was later supported by the Israeli extremist Finance Minister of Salail Smotrich, who called for the "voluntary immigration" of Gaza residents.
In December 2023, invitations returned again when the Israeli Channel 12 revealed that the former British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, discussed with Israeli officials the possibility of moving the Palestinians from Gaza to Arab countries, which Blair later denied.
Trump restores the offering again
In 2025, former US President Donald Trump brought the issue to the fore, when he stated that "Egypt and Jordan have to receive more Palestinian refugees," adding that the two countries "will declare this because we are presenting them a lot." These statements were widely rejected by Cairo and Amman, while the Israeli right was welcomed, headed by resigned National Security Minister Etamar bin Ghafir and Samotrich.
Arab and international rejection: an obstacle to displacement
Over the course of decades, attempts to displace the Palestinians categorically faced the Arab countries, especially Egypt and Jordan, as Cairo fears that any resettlement of the Palestinians in Sinai may pose a threat For its national security, while Jordan rejects the idea of ??the "alternative homeland" that threatens the population composition of the Kingdom.
The international community, including the United Nations and the International Court of Justice, rejected any forced demographic change in the occupied Palestinian territories, as the court demanded in July 2023 (Israel) to stop its procedures that lead to geographical or demographic changes in the Palestinian territories.
Repeated failure ... why?
All Israeli and American attempts to displace Palestinians from Gaza and other occupied areas have not succeeded for several reasons, most notably:
1. The categorical Palestinian rejection: The Palestinians consider the displacement a red line, and they see on staying on the ground as a form of resistance.
2. The decisive Arab position: Despite the pressure, no Arab country agreed to receive refugees as part of the Israeli displacement plans.
3. Legal and international challenges: International law prohibits forced displacement, and the International Court of Justice is a war crime.
4. Political and human cost: Any attempt to displace the Palestinians will lead to regional turmoil and perhaps greater conflicts, which is what the international community realizes.
Palestinian steadfastness outperforms plans Displacement
Despite the long decades of attempts, (Israel) nor its allies have succeeded in implementing the project to displace Palestinians, whether from Gaza or from any other part of the occupied Palestinian territories. The Palestinians remain adhering to their land, and history has proven that the policies of forced displacement will not pass before the steadfastness of a people who are accustomed to resisting the occupation by all possible means.

As soon as the ceasefire agreement in Gaza and the exchange of hostages and prisoners is completed, Gaza has actually entered into the "next day" stage. But that stage has no clear features yet, except what President Donald Trump proposed to Egypt and Jordan, which is to receive more invading refugees in Egypt and Jordan because "they have no shelter in the period of reconstruction." It is a loose proposal, we know when it begins and we do not know when it ends.
Egypt and Jordan rejected Trump's proposal, as was condemned by other Arab countries in addition to the stakeholders because everyone saw in it forcibly an unconvincing migration.
War crime?
The Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949, which is entrusted with forced displacement, is a war crime and prohibits the transfer of the population forcibly under any pretext, and sees any attempt to impose collective displacement an explicit violation of human rights and international law. Such a move will lead to extensive international condemnation and greater internationalization of the crisis, while increasing pressure on Israel and deepening the suffering of the Palestinians.
Is the possibility possible?
Politically, it is believed that it is very difficult for the displacement with the expectation of the spread of the reactions of the Arab countries, officially and popularly, especially in Egypt and Jordan, who realize the seriousness of this The plan that threatens their stability and national security. Collective displacement will be catastrophic from a humanitarian point of view, and causes unprecedented suffering with the absence of infrastructure to receive refugees.
On the popular level, every country that agrees to displace the Palestinians will discover that it threatens its national sovereignty itself, and will face internal and external pressures, and will be accused of collusion in liquidating the Palestinian issue, and participating in emptying Palestine from its residents, and this facilitates Israel imposing new facts without the need for any solution Politics that may be presented.
The repercussions on Palestine
The reality of forced displacement will lead to the displacement of hundreds of thousands of Palestinian families amid harsh conditions such as the shortage of food, medicine and shelter, and the birth of a new catastrophe similar to the 1948 meal aimed at ending the Palestinian presence, ending the dream of a two -state solution, and following the loss of Palestinian national identity. Palestinian refugees will miss stability, as they are firm and national interconnection and the wide humanitarian and economic crises it follows.
The repercussions on Egypt
The first repercussions on Egypt threatening its national security. With large numbers of Palestinian refugees flowing almost The Sinai Island, the demographic structure will change and the security turmoil of the presence of armed groups in this region will be established. These groups may take advantage of the situation after the regime changed in Syria to increase their activities in the Sinai, and expose Egyptian security to unprecedented dangers.
Political and diplomatic repercussions
If Egypt agrees to this plan, it will first be accused of abandoning "the first of the two kisses", and in collusion in the liquidation of the Palestinian cause, and its relations with the Palestinians and the Arab world will be affected. On the other hand, this approval will ignite the wrath of the street inside and outside Egypt, and the Egyptians will refuse to settle the Palestinians in Sinai for national and historical reasons, just as most of them still reject the normalization with Israel for more than forty years. This may lead Egypt to strive with Israel to ward off the pressure of Arab public opinion.
The repercussions on Jordan
In Jordan, the first repercussions is the threat of political and social stability because more than 45% of the population of Jordan is of Palestinian descent and any new wave of displacement would create internal tension in which internal or external forces exploit this situation to stir up chaos or pressure on the Jordanian monarchy, and the threat of the serious threat The other It is the confirmation of Jordan as a "alternative homeland" and the threat of the Jordanian national identity. This is exactly what Jordan has consistently refused because it aims to get rid of the two -state solution at its expense.
Economic pressure
Jordan and Egypt suffer from economic problems. Egypt sees itself besieged by the Ethiopian Renaissance Dam on the one hand, and the Sudanese and Libyan refugees and now the Palestinians, in addition to the low income of the Suez Canal, the rapid population growth and the deterioration of the value of the Egyptian currency towards the dollar. The unemployment rate in Jordan is high and estimated at 17%. If refugees flow from the Palestinian territories, these pressures will intensify on Jordanians, their economy, social services, and their infrastructure, and reflect more unemployment and the high cost of living.
Does Jordan and Egypt strengthen the rejection?
Let us assume that Jordan and Egypt closed their borders and failed forced displacement. Will Israel to dump into cruelty, similar to what it did in Gaza and Lebanon? Or may you resort to a greater military escalation to push the Palestinians to flee by any means, or to impose a more severe siege such as the use of starvation, fuel, medicine and water, an additional means of pressure?
A step of this kind expanded international support for the Palestinian issue, and not Especially in the corridors of the United Nations, and the possibility of more West is the possibility of the support of Israel. Or it prompts these countries to impose economic sanctions on them and to carry out an international and legal movement to try Israel on the war crimes they commit.
Therefore, the only solution that the United States must sponsor, as the great power, is to work to prevent the displacement of Palestinians and to support a fair political solution and pressure to stop Israeli attacks and lift the siege on the West Bank and Gaza and start reconstruction, which helps in a permanent political solution to the Palestinian issue Through the two -state solution, which is the proposed solution to end the Arab -Israeli conflict, according to the decision approved by the Security Council under No. 242, the date November 22, 1967 after the "setback".

At a time when Cairo is preparing to host the emergency Arab summit on February 27, Egyptian Foreign Minister Badr Abdel -Ati began a visit yesterday, Sunday, to Washington, for a plan for the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip during the establishment of an Arab coalition, according to the sources of "Al -Arabi Al -Jadeed ". This visit comes before the emergency Arab summit with the aim of discussing the dangerous developments of the Palestinian issue, especially in light of the statements of US President Donald Trump regarding the displacement of Palestinians from the Gaza Strip, which observers believe is a historical test of the Arab countries to confront the existential threat that threatens not only the Palestinians and their cause, but Also the surrounding Arab countries.

The emergency Arab summit
A statement by the Egyptian Foreign Ministry stated that the emergency Arab summit scheduled for February 27th comes in coordination with Bahrain, the current president of the Arab summit, and the General Secretariat of the League of Arab States, and in consultation with the Arab countries, including the State of Palestine, which requested the holding of this summit. Observers considered that despite the many challenges that The Arab League faces it, but it has the ability to face plans to displace Palestinians by adopting multiple strategies. Among these strategies, the intensification of relief aid and the reconstruction of Gaza, which enhances the steadfastness of the Palestinians on their soil and fails the displacement plans.
Moreover, the Arab League can enhance cooperation with the international community to exert diplomatic pressure on the American administration and Israel to stop any attempts to displace the Palestinians. It can also resort to international bodies, such as the Security Council and the United Nations, to consider any forced displacement as an ethnic cleansing and violation of international law. The Arab League can also study the activation of the joint defense agreement to protect the rights of the Palestinian people, and to send a clear message that the Arab countries are ready to take practical steps to protect the Palestinians.
Special Arab summit in Cairo to discuss facing Trump's plan to displace the people of Gaza
Given the supportive positions of the Palestinian rights by some countries, such as Türkiye, Iran and South Africa, an invitation to these countries can be invited to participate in the efforts of the reconstruction of Gaza. This international cooperation would enhance the effectiveness of the reconstruction process It sends a strong solidarity message with the Palestinian people. Diplomats and experts emphasized that the participants in the emergency Arab summit can take a firm position to reject any attempts to displace the Palestinians from Gaza, whether permanently or temporarily, and considering this a kind of ethnic cleansing. It can also address the international bodies, such as the Security Council and the United Nations, to inform them of the Arab decision rejecting these attempts, and to call for international measures to prevent their implementation.
In this context, the professor of international law Ayman Salama confirmed, in statements to "Al -Arabi Al -Jadeed", that the right of the Palestinian people to self -determination is one of the basic principles in international law, and it is an inaccurate right to act or fall aspiring, as confirmed by United Nations resolutions, Including Resolution No. 3236 issued by the United Nations General Assembly in 1974, which recognizes the right of the Palestinians to self -determination and establish their independent state. Salama added that any attempts to impose forced resettlement on the Palestinians outside their historical land represents a flagrant violation of this right, and constitutes an international crime aimed at liquidating the Palestinian issue and undermining the legitimate struggle of the Palestinian people. He also indicated that the article 49 of the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 prohibits the forced displacement of the population under any circumstance, which means that any attempt to impose the resettlement of the Palestinians in any other country, including Saudi Arabia, contradicts these binding rules for international humanitarian law.

Forced displacement is a war crime
Salama pointed out that the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court defines forced displacement as a war crime and a crime against humanity, which means that any plan aims to force the Palestinians to leave their historical lands under the cover of "resettlement" falls within the scope of international crimes that require accountability and accountability before international courts . Salama stressed that the Arab and Islamic position was evident through the Arab League and the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, as the Arab and Islamic countries rejected any projects aimed at filtering the Palestinian issue or imposing forced solutions that ignore the historical and political rights of the Palestinian people. He stressed that the 2002 Arab Peace Initiative clearly stipulated that the solution The fair to the Palestinian issue must be in accordance with international legitimacy decisions, and not through imposed solutions that detract from the rights of Palestinians and the sovereignty of Arab countries. As for the recent statements of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu regarding the settlement of the Palestinians, he considered it Salama not merely a political provocation, but rather reflects a colonial mentality that tries to impose new facts on the ground by force, in a flagrant challenge to international will and the laws regulating relations between states. However, such attempts will remain rejected by all countries that believe in justice and truth, which have repeatedly emphasized their steadfast support for the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people.

The conversation in political and media circles is renewed about the scenarios of the displacement of population in the Gaza Strip towards Jordanian territory with the escalation of regional tension and the ongoing clashes, and despite the growing conversation and the repetition of direct references to this issue from external parties, the official and popular Jordanian position remained clear and decisive in its rejection of any attempt To impose this scenario on the kingdom, as Jordan considers that passing any plan for collective displacement involves Strategic risks affecting Jordanian sovereignty and national identity, in addition to being a dedication to the occupation and a violation of the fixed rights of the Palestinian people.


Jordan has expressed its repeated rejection of previous localization projects, and in various international forums was keen to find a just and comprehensive solution to the Palestinian issue based on the establishment of an independent Palestinian state and the right to return to refugees, and the Jordanian position rejecting the displacement of the people of Gaza is based on several considerations, most notably that Jordan is carrying over decades Human and economic burdens as a result of hosting large numbers of refugees from neighboring countries, which made the Kingdom's resources and build The infrastructure is in a difficult situation, and any attempt to impose a new resettlement without a comprehensive political solution from It will create an unstable position, and threaten long -term repercussions on the structure of Jordanian society and its national security.

In the face of these renewed pressures, Jordan has political and diplomatic papers that it can wave in defense of its rejectionist position. The Kingdom constitutes an important stability component in the region, and has historical and profound relations with the major countries, in addition to the network of regional and international alliances that realize the importance of the Jordanian role in maintaining balance. Likewise, the international community realizes that any destabilization of Jordanian stability means the escalation of chaos in the region, and this is not what the Europeans and Americans do not want, given the region's sensitivities and the intertwining crises in it, and from here, the security and border coordination that the Kingdom is one of the most important papers, as not Any international entity wants more chaos and chaos on the borders of Israel or in areas close to the areas of burning crisis in the region.


On the other hand, and within the political efforts of His Majesty the King and the delivery of clear and powerful global political messages yesterday, Jordan witnessed a new European support that expressed statements issued by European Union officials, confirming their keenness on the stability and willingness of the Kingdom To provide additional assistance to support its efforts in hosting refugees and economic reform, and although this support is a positive indication of Europe's understanding of the sensitivity of Jordan, it remains dependent on a broader political and economic context, and it is not sufficient to address the roots of Jordan's economic problems and its fears of displacement scenarios, so what Jordan requires At this stage, it is not just financial grants, but rather real political guarantees that maintain the population composition of the Kingdom It prevents the exploitation of the refugee file as a pressure card to liquidate the Palestinian issue.
On the other hand, the American administration's attempts led by Donald Trump, which exerted pressure on Jordan, emerged in the context of what was known as the "deal of the century" previously, and the statements about "Trump's insistence on pressure on Jordan" are still present and directly present; Where some see it as part of a legacy formed its features of broader pressure policies on the countries of the region, these pressures have sought to impose perceptions to settle the Palestinian -Israeli conflict in isolation from the historical rights of the Palestinians, and without regard to the impact of this on the internal conditions of Jordan or the rest of the region.
It is clear that Jordan will not accept any solutions to be seen as a wrap National and national constants, or the Kingdom's transformation into a "alternative homeland" for any other parties, and the Jordanian decision -maker aware that political relations with international powers must be balanced, based on mutual interests and recognition of Jordanian priorities, as Europeans realize, along with some rational American voices, The necessity of Jordan not to deliver in conflicts that do not serve stability in the long run.


Thus, it is confirmed again that the Kingdom, despite its economic challenges and the burden of refugees, has a clear fateful position in rejecting the displacement, and Jordanian diplomacy continues in the international and regional action to deliver a firm message that the solutions of the Palestinian issue must remain confined within the international legal framework in a manner that guarantees the right of the people The Palestinian in the determination of his fate, and although the pressure will not stop, Jordan's steadfastness in this sensitive file He confirms that he is still able to maneuver and defend its constants, no matter how complicated the circumstances appear.

Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El -Sisi confirmed during a joint press conference with the Prime Minister of Spaniadro Sanchezi Madrid today, Wednesday, that regional crises were an important axis in the discussions between the two sides, noting that the developments of the war in the Gaza Strip and the future of the Palestinian issue topped discussions.
President Sisi said: "In this context, we stressed the need for the full implementation of the ceasefire agreement, the continued exchange of hostages and prisoners, and the entry of the necessary humanitarian aid, to save the people of Gaza from the tragic conditions they suffer from." He added: "And allow me from this platform to pay tribute to the courageous and historical decision of Spain, which sided with the right and justice, by recognizing the Palestinian state and the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people, on top of which is its right to self -determination."
Al -Sisi stressed the need to seek and push for the revival of the peace process, with the aim of establishing a Palestinian state, in accordance with international legitimacy resolutions, stressing the importance of supporting the international community for the plan to reconstruct the Gaza Strip from "without the displacement of the Palestinian people, and I repeat without the displacement of the Palestinian people from their lands in which they adhere to, and their homeland that It does not accept neglecting it, "to ensure the immediate start of Relief and early recovery operations. He also called for the support of international humanitarian organizations in the humanitarian field, led by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees (UNRWA), which cannot be dispensed with in providing basic humanitarian services to the Palestinian people.
Special The postponement of Sisi's visit to Washington until after the Cairo summit
Sanchez: "We strongly reject the displacement of the Palestinians from Gaza"
For his part, Spain Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez confirmed his country rejecting forced displacement of the Palestinians, stressing that "Gaza for the Palestinians and its future is Palestinian," describing the expulsion of the Palestinians from the Strip as "an immoral act that contradicts international law and United Nations decisions, and will be a destabilizing reason for stability at the level Regional and international. Sanchez also praised the Egyptian efforts to achieve the ceasefire in Gaza, and to verify the implementation of the agreement, stressing that "the time has come to move to the second stage of the agreement, which must include the liberation of all hostages and the arrival of humanitarian aid to the Gaza Strip intensively."
The Prime Minister of Spain expressed his country's support for the upcoming Arab summit in Cairo on March 4 Next, saying: "We support the proposal in which the Arab Summit for the Reconstruction of Gaza will come out," noting that Spain has soldiers in the European Mission to monitor the Rafah crossing, and also supports the peace summit conference to be held in New York in June, stressing the importance of European dialogue Arab in this regard. Sanchez pointed out that the world is going through "mysterious and confused circumstances", which makes cooperation between the partners more important, stressing that "Egypt and Spain can, through the strategic partnership between them, open a new stage full of capabilities to build relations that are grateful for more prosperity and prosperity for the two peoples."
Enhancing bilateral relations: signing the strategic partnership agreement
The Egyptian President explained that his second visit to Madrid reflects "the sincere desire to enhance the established historical relations between the two countries, and the fruitful cooperation between them, on a joint basis of mutual respect and understanding." Al -Sisi revealed the signing of a document "to raise Egyptian Spanish relations to the level of strategic partnership", confirming Cairo's aspiration to implement it effectively "side by side, with all agreements and memoranda of understanding concluded between us, with the aim of deepening Economic and investment cooperation, and the increase in the volume of trade exchange between the two countries, which were the things that have been of great importance during our talks today.
In the same context, Sanchez stressed that "today is very important because Spain and Egypt have decided to raise bilateral relations to a strategic partnership rank, and then we have the political framework that this cooperation deserves."
Al -Sisi also stressed the need to "enhance the presence of Spanish investments, and build on the success stories of Spanish companies operating in Egypt", as well as intensifying cooperation in the localization of the industry in Egypt in the fields of renewable energy, transport, communications and information technology, in addition to exchanging experiences in managing and developing water resources, in What the issue of water security represented is extremely important to Egypt. "
In this regard, the Spanish Prime Minister indicated that "many Spanish companies want to participate in the strategic projects launched by the government of Egypt, and there are great possibilities to enhance this presence, stressing that the business forum that will be held this evening will be an opportunity to discover more investment opportunities."
Sanchez also stressed that "Egypt is one of the main countries that receive official funding for Development, especially in the railway sector, through the Business Fund and the Spanish Agency for Export Loan Credit.
