US President Donald Trump's retreat from his statements about the Gaza Strip threatening questions about whether this decline means a failure to implement its policies, or that it is just a tactic aimed at achieving gains in favor of Israel.

A book, political analysts, specialists and university professors believe in separate conversations with "?", Trump's retreat is not a strategic change. Rather, tactically, and that Trump is still committed to the application of plans that may lead to fundamental changes in the Palestinian scene, noting that the United States may withdraw from the role of the direct mediator in negotiations, allowing Israel freedom to make more influential decisions on the future of the sector.

The writers, analysts, specialists, and university professors confirm that political pressures from the Arab countries and the Palestinian people had a great impact on the amendment of the American position, which led to Trump's retreat from his exaggerated threats, and that this change reflects the failure of the method of "diplomatic edge of the abyss" that Trump relied on in Click on the parties concerned to achieve its goals.

And they point out that the concerns are increasing that Trump's statements may be just a tool to impose a new political reality in Gaza, as Trump is working to enhance pressure on the Palestinian resistance to make concessions that may lead to changes in the political and military scene of the region.

Trump retracted his threats due to the unified Arab position

The writer and political analyst specializing in Israeli affairs, Dr. Hussein Al -Deek, believes that US President Donald Trump's retreat from his threats on the Gaza Strip came as a result of a unified Arab position. Stressing that the collective political will by Arab governments and peoples is able to break American pressure and positions.

The rooster explains that the United States, despite its arrogance, is not an inevitable amount, and its policies can be faced and thwarted if there is a strict and clear Arab position.

Al -Deek notes that Trump's retreat from his hostile statements on Gaza reflects his failure to use what is known as the "brink of the abyss", which is based on severe pressure to achieve political goals.

Al -Deek explains that this method did not succeed in the stiffness of the Arab position rejecting his statements, which assured the world that Trump is a dialectical and popular figure, and he often issues narcissistic statements that are not implemented.

Regarding the issue of Israeli prisoners and detainees in the Gaza Strip, Al -Deek confirms that the Hamas movement showed a clear commitment to the signed agreement, which requires the release of three prisoners per week according to the specified plan, indicating that any violation of this agreement came from the Israeli side with American support.

Al -Deek notes that the Israeli occupation did not abide by the humanitarian part of the agreement, as it prevented the entry of the necessary equipment to remove the rubble, and it was not allowed to enter the houses. Mobile and agreed tents.

The rooster asserts that Israel's approval of the deal came under great internal pressure, as the Benjamin Netanyahu government faces pressure from the Haredim parties and from the Israeli street, in addition to the position of the military establishment that exhausted its goals in Gaza, which prompted Netanyahu to move forward despite its frequency.

On the expected scenarios of the future of the agreement, the rooster explains that there are four possible scenarios: either the completion of the stages of the deal as planned, although this scenario appears weak due to Netanyahu's delay in completing the first stage, especially since the second stage of negotiations has not started yet, and remains less than Two weeks since the end of the first stage.

As for the scenario, the second scenario, according to the rooster, is related to the tour of US Secretary of State Marco Rubio in the Middle East, where he visited Tel Aviv, then a number of Arab countries, to discuss new arrangements aimed at expanding and extending the first stage of the agreement.

The rooster explains that this scenario has the support of Netanyahu, who convinced the Americans, but his success depends on the position of Hamas and the extent of Israel's commitment to implementing the initial agreement.

The rooster indicates that the scenario The third is linked to the Arab summit to be held in Cairo on the 27th of this month.
Al-Deek notes that media reports talk about an Egyptian-Arab initiative on the management of the Gaza Strip, which includes the management of the sector through Palestinian experts and technicians under Arab and international supervision, with Hamas excluded from the ruling.

Al -Deek believes that this scenario is likely, given the Palestinian and Arab rejection of the plan to displace the people of Gaza, and the severe Israeli opposition to the return of the Palestinian Authority to the Strip.

With regard to the fourth scenario, according to the rooster, it is based on the return of military operations in the Gaza Strip after the end of the first stage of the agreement.

The rooster considers that this scenario is weak, justifying that the Trump administration looks at the region from the perspective of commercial deals, not wars, and that the resumption of war will hinder the investment plans that the American administration desires, especially from the Gulf states.

Al-Deek notes that the upcoming meeting between Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin in Saudi Arabia may contribute to strengthening American-Arab understandings and reducing the chances of military escalation.

The rooster confirms that the unified Arab position and regional understandings play a pivotal role in the face of American and Israeli policies, which makes the unity of the Arab ranks a major tool for protecting national and national interests in the next stage.

Trump did not retract his initial plans to displace the Gazans

The writer and political researcher d. Tamara Haddad said that US President Donald Trump has not retracted his initial plans related to the forced displacement of the Palestinians in the Gaza Strip, but rather is still determined to implement these plans.

Haddad notes that Trump has handed over the final decision to implement this deal to Israel, considering that the United States of America will remain part of ensuring the implementation of the agreements related to Gaza, but it is retracting its role as a major decision maker, and therefore, Israel will have the freedom to make final decisions regarding the deal, This reflects the complete intersection between Trump and the thought of the Israeli government, which seeks to produce the largest possible number of Israeli prisoners.

Haddad explains that the decline that appeared in Trump's statements is not a strategic decline, but a tactical, as the implementation of the first stage of the deal, which includes the removal of the prisoners, is in the interest of Israel.

Haddad notes that this stage may extend for a longer period than The expected, as Israel seeks to collect the largest possible number of hostages, to ensure a pressure tool on the Palestinian side.

Haddad believes that the equation imposed in the first stage of the deal is a purely human equation, so that humanitarian aid and residential caravans are introduced in exchange for the removal of Israeli hostages, and therefore any progress towards the second or third stages of the deal will only take place on specific conditions, set by the Israeli Prime Minister. Benjamin Netanyahu, among these conditions, highlights the demand to remove the leading leaders of Hamas from the Gaza Strip, in addition to ensuring that the sector is not It poses a future threat to Israeli national security.

Haddad notes that Israel does not want to enter the second and third phases of the deal at the present time, due to the security and economic benefits that may entail it, such as the full withdrawal from Gaza and the reconstruction.

Haddad pointed out that Israel does not want to perform the reconstruction process quickly, as it considers that the Palestinian citizen may be proven on his land even if the reconstruction is temporary, which enhances his resilience.

Haddad believes that the primary goal of the American and Israeli escalation is Imposing a new reality in Gaza, with a focus on the human equation in exchange for taking the hostages.

On the Arab level, Haddad confirms that there is an urgent need for a coordinated Arab plan to confront the Israeli and American plans related to displacement.

Haddad considers that the Arab plan may focus on removing Hamas from the political scene to withdraw excuses from Israel and the United States of America, while emphasizing the need for this plan to be acceptable to Palestinian, regionally and internationally.

Haddad explains that the situation in Gaza may lead to the extension of the first stage of the deal or to form a transitional stage similar to the first stage, in an attempt by the Israeli and American parties to pressure Hamas more through the worsening human reality.

Haddad confirms that the political future in Gaza remains mysterious, and that the situation requires urgent Arab coordination to face the challenges that occur in the Palestinian issue.

Arab and regional moves that started to provide alternatives and plans

The writer and political analyst Suleiman Bisharat believes that the high statements made by Trump on Gaza carry a major goal to raise the ceiling in the rhythm of the parties concerned in a state of shock. With the aim of rearranging priorities in line with the Israeli -American vision of the region.

It was terrified, according to Bisharat, through these statements, he wanted to introduce new variables in the conflict based on Gaza, especially as it relates to the future of the Strip after the war, and to restore a balance between the active forces in the region, and his open threat to open the "doors of hell" as he described it, and affirming the possibility of disrupting The agreements if their path is not adhered to, a pressure tool to force the parties to comply with Washington's vision.

Bisharat believes that the second goal of this escalation is to activate the populist discourse that resonates with the hard -line Israeli right, which enhances the consensus between the American and Israeli position. Thus, Trump wanted, in addition to making the Israeli position more in line with the American vision, which explains the escalation of the speech and then retracting it after a short period.

With the American retreat from some statements, Bisharat believes that Trump may have achieved his basic goals, which was a shock to the parties concerned and forced them to amend their policies, and thus began to rearrange the papers according to the American vision.

Bisharat indicates the presence of Arab moves Regionalism began to provide alternatives and plans to deal with the future situation in Gaza, which reflects the impact of American statements in igniting new dynamics in the region.

Bisharat believes that Trump's implementation of his threats is very difficult, as the Palestinians in Gaza have lost everything, and they have nothing to lose if they decide to reject what the United States is proposing, and the catastrophic humanitarian situation in the sector made it difficult for America to appear as the weak in Confronting the destruction left by the war.

Bisharat considers that the Palestinian resistance has proven its ability to absorb American and Israeli pressure, as it dealt with caution and realism with events in order to avoid granting Israel or Trump the excuse to resume the war or escalation.

The resistance, according to Bisharat, realizes that things are no longer just improvised reactions, but rather have become part of accurate political accounts that include the Palestinian, international and regional dimensions.

Bisharat believes that the current situation is still mysterious, and there is no real perception of the parties concerned on how to deal with Gaza after the war, and despite the passage of more than 15 months of the war, the parties have not reached final solutions on the future The politician of the sector, however, there are perceptions and visions circulating by these parties, but they will not be effective, unless there is a consensus between all parties.

Bisharat explains that the most realistic scenario for the next stage indicates that there is a kind of balance between the Palestinian resistance and Israel, with the support of the United States, and in this scenario, any proposed agreement will be a consensus between the Palestinian resistance and the international parties.

The other scenario, according to Bisharat, is the crazy scenario in which Israel, led by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, may seek to exploit the hesitant American position to pressure the other parties to achieve its political goals.

Bisharat believes that the situation in the Gaza Strip will remain in a state of constant instability, as long as the existing agreements will not be fixed or easily implemented, which makes them vulnerable to the manipulation of the various parties and the introduction of changes that may empty the agreements from their content, and therefore the Palestinian situation in Gaza remains its place in A circle of political escalation, until real consensus is reached that guarantee long -term stability.

Trump from the role of the mediator to a direct party in the pressure

The writer and political researcher, Dr. Salah's mind that US President Donald tried, through his promises, attempted to exert extensive pressure on the resistance to accept the conditions of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, and despite this, Trump was aware that the resistance would not be acquies from these threats.

Salah notes that Trump also practiced pressure on the Qatari and Egyptian intermediaries to push them to influence the resistance, which led to the implementation of the sixth batch of the deal, but Israel has dismissed its obligations and refused to enter aid to Gaza after that.

Salah confirms that the major crisis lies in the fact that Trump, who is supposed to be a mediator and a security of the agreement, is the one who encouraged Netanyahu to violate it, which represents a serious precedent in the role of international mediators, through this absolute support for Israel, and Trump is seeking to save Netanyahu from the responsibility for disrupting the agreement And hold the resistance responsibility instead.

Salah refers to Trump's transformation from the role of the mediator to a direct party to pressure the resistance, with the aim of reducing its political and field achievements.

Salah explains that Israel broke up for the sixth batch due to the increasing pressure from the Israeli street and the Trump administration, as Netanyahu seeks to Achieving gains through negotiations did not achieve through the war.

Salah expects the American pressure to continue the resistance to push it to a settlement that gives Netanyahu a political achievement that preserves the cohesion of his government coalition and provides a moral victory for Israel.

Salah warns that the seventh batch of the deal is facing the risk of disruption due to the disintegration of Israel from the introduction of humanitarian aid, stressing that the resistance may refuse to complete the deal unless Israel is committed to the terms of the agreement.
Salah believes that the next stage will be arduous, as its success is closely related to the movement of the Israeli street to pressure his government.

Salah notes that the post -war American arrangements in Gaza place resistance in front of major challenges, as it cannot rely on the role of brokers without clear guarantees to implement the agreed humanitarian obligations.


Multiple angles to explain Trump's threats

Dr. Raed Al -Dubai, Head of Political Science at An -Najah National University, believes that Trump's retreat from his previous threats, which included "opening the gates of hell" if not all Israeli hostages are released by Saturday, can be explained by several angles.

Al -Dabi considers that the threats he made Trump is commensurate with his populist and emotional personality, as he is known for his escalating and exaggerated style in his speeches, and therefore his threats to Hamas was part of this approach that depends on shock and exaggeration with the aim of attracting attention, without necessarily having a realistic plan to implement these threats.

Al -Dabi is cited previous experiences of Trump, where he fired fiery statements and then retracted it when he discovered that they are not implementable or when he faced internal or external pressures. For example, during his first term, Trump had issued threats against North Korea and China, but he returned later to change His positions after realizing that these threats may lead to reverse results.

Al -Dubai believes that Trump's great pressure from his advisers in the American administration, in addition to international pressure from allies and partners in the region, especially in the context of mediation on the exchange deal, which led him to adopt a more cautious and coordination position with Israel.

Al -Dabi believes that Trump was seeking to present himself as a firefighting man in the world, especially with regard to the Palestinian file, as he had succeeded in a ceasefire previously, and from here, the escape of matters at this time, Before returning the detainees, he contradicts the image he wants to hold for himself.

Al -Dabi believes that Israel, on the other hand, chose to put its national interests above any other consideration, which explains its approval to complete the prisoner exchange deal despite Trump's threats.

Al -Dabi considers that this Israeli position reflects the effectiveness of indirect negotiations and a real desire to restore the detainees, which may be the result of internal pressure from the families of the hostages and the Israeli public opinion.

As for the future scenarios, Al -Dabi believes that the Hamas and Islamic Jihad movement possesses prisoners, especially the neighborhoods of them, and that the second stage of the deal, which includes the release of intelligence officers, may put Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu under great pressure.

Al -Dabi believes that Netanyahu will make an effort to extend the first phase of the deal in order to avoid discussing the issue of stopping the war, which may affect the stability of his government coalition, but Al -Dabi indicates that, in the end, Netanyahu will have to discuss the second stage of the deal, which includes a comprehensive ceasefire of shooting .

With regard to Netanyahu's position on the end of the war, Al -Dabi believes that the Prime Minister The Israeli does not want a comprehensive stop of the fire, because it means his exit from the government and political scene, but at the same time he does not have many options due to the increasing pressure from home and abroad.

According to Da`i, the features of the second stage of the deal will determine a set of data and developments, including the position of the American administration, the pressure that it may exercise on Israel, in addition to the developments of the military field.
He points out that Netanyahu is not the only player who decides in these circumstances, but will rely in the future on the balance of strength at home and abroad to determine his directions.

Trump's character is governed by the merchant's mindset

The writer and political analyst Sri Samour believes that the personality of US President Donald Trump is governed by the merchant's mindset, as he used to put forward very high demands with the aim of obtaining negotiating gains, which was reflected in his behavior towards Gaza.

Samour notes that this approach is derived from the background of Trump in the real estate sector, as it depends on the maximum bargaining to achieve its goals, despite the presence of American institutions that limit its decisions.

Samour explains that Trump tends to escalate, but he is retreating to diplomacy whenever he faces real resistance to his proposals, citing the transformation of his positions from Russian President Vladimir Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, who moved from the threat to rapprochement after realizing their hardness.

On the Israeli scene, Samour indicates unannounced arrangements between Washington and Tel Aviv that go beyond Trump's public statements, but he believes that the United States, at this stage, will not provide financial and military support to Israel with the same generosity that President Joe Biden provided.

Samour explains that Israel is seeking to resume the war in Gaza and cancel the second stage of the agreement or integrate it according to its own conditions, continuing to fabricate crises to achieve its goals.

Samour warns of a catastrophic scenario of pushing the Arab countries to provide bad solutions for fear of Trump's threats to displace the inhabitants of Gaza, as this fear may lead to crystallizing uncomfortable Arab plans aimed at only thwarting the displacement plan.

Samour notes that there is a media reading that Trump's statements aim to restore the image of the Arab regimes that have received widespread criticism because of its silence during the events of Gaza, but it does not tend to this opinion, but rather believes that Trump's goal is to push the Arabs to formulate a political plan, which may not include a displacement In full, but a partial displacement that holds consequences Dangerous.

Samour emphasizes the importance of Arab caution against drifting behind any uncompromising plans, stressing that the stage requires a deep political awareness to face a dangerous wrap scenarios on the Palestinian issue.

The Kremlin said on Monday that the talks scheduled for Tuesday in Saudi Arabia between Russian officials and high -ranking Americans aim to bridge the rift in bilateral relations and will also include "possible negotiations on Ukraine" and preparing a summit between Trump and Putin.

The Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said that the talks between the two sides "will be devoted primarily to rebuild Russian -American relations in all fields."

Peskov told reporters that Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov and the diplomatic advisor to President Vladimir Putin, Yuri Ushakov will go to Riyadh to participate in the meeting.

"Secretary of State Marco Rubio, National Security Adviser Mike Waltz and US President Donald Trump's special envoy to the Middle East, Steve Witkeov, will meet the Russian delegation in Riyadh on Tuesday," before the upcoming Summit between Trump and Putin.

For his part, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said on Monday before heading to Riyadh that in their phone call last week, "Putin and Trump agreed on the need to leave the completely abnormal relations behind them," adding that "the two presidents They agreed on the necessity of resuming the dialogue. "
Russia is seeking to reorganize the security structure on the European continent, as it called for the withdrawal of NATO forces from Eastern European countries.

The Kremlin says that the invasion of Ukraine was aimed at addressing the existential threat of NATO.

Peskov said that the Riyadh meeting "will also be devoted to preparing for possible negotiations to settle the situation in Ukraine and organize the meeting between the two presidents."

He added that the Middle East may also be at the talk table, as the two countries compete to acquire influence and after the collapse of Bashar al -Assad's rule in Syria and the setback of Iran.

Rubio arrived in Saudi Arabia on Monday.

Lavrov said on Sunday that "nothing has been completed yet" with regard to talks aimed at ending the war in Ukraine.

Trump's connection to Putin last week was the shock in Europe, especially after announcing their agreement to start negotiations "immediately" on Ukraine, which has not yet been known how to participate.

An official source said that Volodimir Zellinski will visit Saudi Arabia on Wednesday.

The Europeans are afraid of being excluded from negotiations, and therefore they meet in Paris on Monday for the agreement On a common position.
Lavrov said on Monday that he did not see a reason that calls for the participation of Europeans in the peace talks in Ukraine. "I do not know what they will do at the negotiating table ... if they will sit around the negotiating table in order to continue the war, then why do we invite them to it?" He added.

70 human rights and religious organizations in the United States rejected the plan that US President Donald Trump put forward to displace the Palestinians from the Gaza Strip, two days after more than two -thirds of the members of Congress announced their rejection of this plan.
In a common message sent by organizations to Trump, she expressed their "deep concern" about the plan, calling on him to benefit from the previous diplomatic efforts that resulted in the ceasefire in Gaza, instead of taking policies that may contribute to destabilizing the region.
In its message, which was published on Friday, the organizations explained that "the American ethnic cleansing and the Gaza occupation will lead to a violent reaction in the Arab and Islamic world, and will cause American resources to deplete by involvement in new wars, which makes the establishment of a peaceful Palestinian state impossible and increases from The conflict in the region. "
The organizations stressed that "Gaza is not just a plot of land for sale for those who pay more, but rather a homeland for a Palestinian people who consider it homeland for generations." Trump called for abandoning the proposal to expel the Palestinians, and start working with the Arab and Islamic world to develop a practical plan to rebuild Gaza without the displacement of its people.
It was among Organizations that signed the message of the Council of American Islamic Relations (CAIR), the American Muslim Muslims for Palestine (amp), "Codepink", and "PEACE Action", as well as many other organizations.
This comes two days after 145 members of Congress signed a message in which they demanded Trump to retract his statements regarding the "seizing" the United States on the Gaza Strip, considering this a dangerous step that threatens stability in the region.

She added that the outcome of the injuries has risen to 111,091 wounded, since the aggression began, while thousands of victims are still under the rubble.

A diplomatic source revealed to the island that the Confederation of Peace and Security Council will hold an exceptional summit in mid -February on Sudan.

The source pointed out that the summit - which will be held at the level of heads of state and governments - aims to assess the current situation in Sudan, discuss accelerating developments, and set a road map to achieve a ceasefire.

This summit comes after victories achieved by the Sudanese army on the Rapid Support Forces during the past days by breaking the siege on the headquarters of the General Command of the Army and the signal weapon and regaining control of most of the city of Bahri north of Khartoum and the city of Umm Rawaba in the state of North Kordofan and the city of Wad Madani, the capital of Al Jazeera.

Since April 2023, Sudan has been witnessing a bloody conflict between the army led by Abdel -Fattah al -Burhan and the Rapid Support Forces led by its former deputy, Muhammad Hamdan Daglo, nicknamed "Hamidati".

The two parties to the conflict faces accusations of war crimes, especially targeting civilians, launching random shelling on homes, markets and hospitals, and obstructing the entry and distribution of humanitarian aid.

The conflict in Sudan led to a huge humanitarian catastrophe with the killing of tens of thousands and the displacement of more than 12 million people, while that Millions on the brink of starvation.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu pledged to eliminate Hamas in the Gaza Strip and restore all Israeli hostages who are still being held there, in a video message broadcast on his office, on Saturday evening.
"We will eliminate (Hamas) and restore our hostages (...), this is what we will do," Netanyahu said in the letter that was presented after a new exchange that included three Israeli hostages and more than 180 Palestinian detainees.

Before that, Netanyahu announced the sending of a delegation to Doha to conduct negotiations dealing with the next stage of the armistice between the Hebrew state and "Hamas" in Gaza, and began to be implemented on January 19.

A statement of the Netanyahu office stated that after a new exchange, on Saturday, for Israeli hostages in Gaza in exchange for Palestinians that Israel is arrested, "Netanyahu ordered the sending of a delegation to Qatar, and upon his return from the United States, he intends to hold a meeting of the security government on this issue."

Today, Hamas released 3 Israeli hostages who spent 16 months detained in the Gaza Strip, while Israel released 183 Palestinian detainees in the fifth exchange of the ceasefire agreement.

The three hostages are transported by Levi (34 years), Elie Sharabi (52 years old), and the German -Israeli, Ohhhad bin Ami (56 years old), in trucks, and they were climbed by Hamas fighters to a platform during a ceremony organized by the movement in Deir Al -Balah in the central Gaza Strip.

They were then handed over to the "International Red Cross", which in turn delivered them to the Israeli authorities.

In exchange for the launch of the three hostages, Israel released 183 Palestinians, according to the Israeli Prison Authority.

The Euro -Mediterranean Observatory warned of the escalation of forced displacement waves carried out by the Israeli army against the Palestinians in the West Bank, describing it as "a reproduction of the crime of genocide." The Observatory confirmed that the Israeli military operations in the Al -Fara'a refugee camp in Tubas, which started since the second of February, included wide raids and the destruction of homes and infrastructure, in addition to imposing a curfew.
According to the observatory reports, the pressure that resulted from the siege, starvation, and threats to bombing homes have pushed hundreds of Palestinian families to forcibly displacement, amid harsh conditions, as these families were forced to leave their homes through paths identified by the Israeli forces.
The Observatory continued that the occupation army had displaced the majority of the residents of Jenin camp, whose number is estimated at more than 13,000 Palestinians, in addition to the displacement of more than 11,000 residents of the Tulkarm and Nour Shams camps. The Observatory considered these operations one of the broadest campaigns of forced displacement in the West Bank for decades.
The report indicated that the displacement operations were not limited to expelling civilians from their homes, but rather included the destruction and burning of homes, and the destruction of the structure Infrastructure, cutting electricity, water and communications supplies, with the aim of creating harsh living conditions. He also pointed out that the killing policy targeted 35 Palestinians, including five children and two women, during 19 days of aggression, in addition to the injury of about 300 others.
The Euro -Mediterranean Observatory warned that the continued "Israel" impunity for its crimes in Gaza encourages it to expand its aggression in the West Bank, with the risk of committing the same crime of genocide.
At the end of its report, the observatory called on the international community to immediately intervene to stop the Israeli military operations in the West Bank, ensure the protection of Palestinian civilians, and pressure "Israel" to stop its intention to include the West Bank and impose sovereignty over it.

A person was martyred as a result of the targeting of an Israeli path of a vehicle on the sea road of the city of Sidon in southern Lebanon; Monday morning.

The Lebanese Agency reported the targeting of a car near Rafik Hariri's sports city at the northern entrance to Sidon.

This comes with the intensification of the Israeli army, its aggression against Lebanon, before the completion of its supposed withdrawal from southern Lebanon scheduled for tomorrow, Tuesday.

It is not yet known whether Israel will adhere to the date of completion of its withdrawal or will be dismissed from it, as it has been shown from the previous date.

In the context of the continuous violations, an Israeli force penetrated towards the center of the town of Kafrshoba in the Hasbaya district of Nabatieh Governorate, after the Lebanese army spread in it, as well as the town of Mahalla Al -Sawan with bombs and light and medium machine guns; According to the Lebanese Agency, Monday morning.

The agency also reported that the Israeli army was burning from the early morning hours of Lebanese homes in the border town of Adisa.

It was supposed to complete the Israeli army at dawn on January 26 last, its withdrawal from the areas it occupied in southern Lebanon, according to the deadline specified in the ceasefire agreement between Beirut and Tel Aviv, and adult 60 days, starting from entering into force on November 27, 2024.
And Reuters reported last week that Tel Aviv asked the ICRC to monitor the agreement to extend the survival of its forces until February 28, for an additional ten days, which Beirut rejected.

This committee consists of Lebanon, Israel, the United States, France and the United Nations Interim Force Southern Lebanon.

Since the agreement, Israel has committed 925 violations in Lebanon, which left 74 martyrs and 265 wounded; Based on Lebanese official data.

Israel's aggression against Lebanon began on October 8, 2023, and turned into a widespread war on September 23, and resulted in 4 thousand and 104 martyrs and 16 thousand and 890 wounded, including a large number of children and women, in addition to displacing about one million and 400 thousand people.

The Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mohamed Mustafa, discussed today, Tuesday and the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Portugal, Paulo Rangel, the developments of the situation in Palestine, in light of the continued aggression of the occupation in the northern West Bank areas, in addition to the relief government efforts in the Gaza Strip.

Upon his reception, the Prime Minister reviewed his Portuguese guest in Ramallah, in the presence of the Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Faris Shaheen, the relief governmental efforts on the ground in the Gaza Strip, through the leadership of the government operations room and coordination with all relief institutions operating in the sector, to ensure the optimal distribution of aid and provide temporary accommodation And the restoration of partially destroyed housing units, the removal of the rubble and the restoration of basic services, In preparation for comprehensive reconstruction.

He said that Israel is seeking to destroy the West Bank, by continuing to invade cities, towns, villages and camps in the northern West Bank, and the killings and arrests, and the destruction of homes, facilities and infrastructure on a daily basis.

Mustafa stressed the rejection of all plans to displace our people from the Gaza Strip, and the plans of annexation in the West Bank, which destroys the embodiment of the establishment of the Palestinian state on the ground.

He also stressed the importance The implementation of the UN Security Council Resolution 2735, which confirms the ceasefire permanently, the introduction of aid to the Gaza Strip, the unification of institutions between the West Bank and the Strip, the preparation for reconstruction, and the embodiment of the establishment of the Palestinian state.

Mustafa appreciated Portugal's support and its steadfast stance towards Palestine and the legitimate rights of our people in all international forums.

For his part, the Portuguese Foreign Minister expressed his solidarity with our people, especially in the Gaza Strip, stressing the need for more relief in the Strip and the sustainability of the ceasefire, the need for Israel to adhere to international and humanitarian law, and the government receive the tasks of its work in the sector completely, unify the institutions, and support efforts Government reform, in addition to rejecting colonialism and the plans of annexation in the West Bank, displacing citizens from the Gaza Strip, embodying the establishment of the Palestinian state, and supporting UNRWA And ensuring that its work continues to provide services to Palestinian refugees.

The United Nations Humanitarian Coordination Office "OCHA" said that more than 376,000 Palestinians have returned to the northern Gaza Strip between Monday morning and on Tuesday.

The office explained that half of these displaced men are men, while a quarter of them are women and the other quarter of children.

The "Ocha" office was based on the numbers of a working group that includes several organizations that set up census points throughout the sector.

The office said, "Pregnant women, breastfeeding women, elderly people, people with disabilities and with chronic diseases or in need of urgent medical care, or minors who are not accompanied by their relatives are among the main major groups of the displaced who made this difficult trip on foot."

The national and Islamic forces in the Gaza Strip warned that the Palestinian people are facing an existential threat with the escalation of displacement plans, stressing that these projects will not be limited to the Gaza Strip, but will extend to the West Bank in an attempt to liquidate the Palestinian issue.

During the conference, which was followed by Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, the national forces called for an urgent meeting for the general secretaries of the Palestinian factions, with the aim of coordinating positions and taking steps to confront the current challenges, stressing that the Palestinian rank unity is a need to confront these risks.
The national and Islamic forces condemned the statements of US President Donald Trump regarding the displacement of Palestinians from Gaza, describing it as a declaration of war aimed at uprooting the Palestinians from their land. The national and Islamic forces concluded their statement by emphasizing that the Palestinian people will remain steadfast in the face of all attempts to liquidate and uproot, and that any attempt to impose a new reality will be faced with a unified resistance from the Palestinian people in all places of their existence.

Al -Quds University and the International Labor Organization (ILO) signed a partnership agreement during a ceremony held at the headquarters of the Ministry of Labor, in the presence of the President of the University, Prof. Dr. Imad Abu Kishek, as well as representatives of the donors and the partner to celebrate an important step towards empowering Palestinian youth through cooperative entrepreneurship and social innovation.

This project comes within the Cooperative Support Program for Palestine (CSP-Opt), with funding from the Italian Agency for Development Cooperation (AICS).

The agreement employs the integration of Think.coop and Start.coop tools for the International Labor Organization in Business Incubators Programs at Al -Quds University, paving the way for innovative cooperative models, pioneering training, and financial support for entrepreneurial projects led by young people in the fields of technology, renewable energy, health care and digital media.

The spokesperson for the parties to the agreement emphasized the importance of integrating efforts to confront unemployment among young people and enhance comprehensive economic growth, pointing to their aspiration to support the next generation of Palestinian innovators and consolidate the foundations of cooperation for a sustainable prosperity in the long term.

The signing ceremony was concluded for a number of main steps: the launch of a business plans competition The cooperative aims to discover and support the creative and socially influential cooperative models, developing specialized training and guidance programs to enhance the skills of young entrepreneurs, providing sustainable investment opportunities that support youth projects, and enhance economic and social resilience in the occupied Palestinian land.

The comprehensive periodic review of the human rights situation is a mechanism that follows it The United Nations to review the human rights situation in member states every four years to verify the states seeking to improve it, and to show the extent of their commitment to the covenants of human rights that have been pledged to fulfill.
A report was submitted and discussed on January 28, through its delegation, to the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva, which was headed by Egyptian Foreign Minister Badr Abdel -Ati.
Abdel -Ati said that Egypt rejected 71 recommendations out of a total of 372 recommendations made during the session.
Among the recommendations rejected by Cairo is the abolition of the death penalty, as Abdel -Ati stressed that the Egyptian constitution and law "stipulate this punishment as a deterrent measure of specific crimes, stressing that it is carried out with strict guarantees, such as the multiplicity of litigation of litigation, and the need for the courts of the Court of Cassation to support the ruling, to The final certification of the President of the Republic.
During his speech, the Egyptian Foreign Minister referred to the National Human Rights Strategy, which included the abolition of the state of emergency, the activation of the Presidential Pardon Committee, and the launch of social initiatives such as the project (a decent life) and the program (Takaful and Dignity), to improve the standard of living of citizens.
The minister also stressed "efforts to amend national legislation, such as The National Labor Law and the new criminal procedure law, "pointing to Egypt's hosting of more than 10.7 million migrants and refugees, and providing them with basic services.
On December 17, 2024, 12 Egyptian human rights organizations have published a joint report on what it described as "the exacerbation of the human rights crisis in Egypt during the past five years." The organizations presented a copy of this report to the United Nations before Cairo reviewed their legal file for the fourth time this year ago, a few days after three times in 2010, 2014 and 2019.
"The Egyptian government's initiatives such as issuing what is known as the national human rights strategy, the presidential amnesty committee, and the national dialogue are just cosmetic steps that have no real influence," says Mohamed Zuharah, director of the Cairo Center for Human Rights Studies, for the BBC, who is one of the participants in this report.
"What we monitored in the report from human rights violations in Egypt, such as violations related to the right to life and combating execution, torture and forced concealment, the conditions of places of detention, the length of pretrial detention, and the continuation of imprisonment in opinion issues, means that there is no progress since the review Previous in 2019.
For his part, Tariq Al -Khouli, Undersecretary of the Foreign Relations Committee in the House of Representatives and a member of the Presidential Pardon Committee, sees BBC that Egypt is working to advance the conditions of human rights in it as a national will, and not only in order to review its international file, which is also an important measure of the extent of progress What Egypt made in this file.
Al -Khouli adds that "there are achievements for the Egyptian state in the field of civil and political human rights in response to the recommendations that Egypt accepted in the previous review in 2019, such as the new criminal procedures law, amendments to the Prison Organization Law in addition to preparing the laws of foreign asylum, the practice of civil action, the National Dialogue Initiative, and the Presidential Pardon Committee ".
Al -Khouli is an example of the amendment of the Criminal Procedure Law recently regarding the pre -trial detention that was one of the most prominent recommendations addressed to Egypt, as the new law reduced the maximum period of pre -trial detention in misdemeanors to 4 months instead of 6 months, and in crimes to 12 months instead of 18 months, But if the penalty prescribed for the crime is life imprisonment or death, then the maximum period of reserve imprisonment is 18 months instead. Trump's vision of the rehabilitation of the Gaza Strip is based on purely economic and utilitarian considerations, but it ignores the deep connection of the Palestinians with their land, which is still an essential component of the Palestinian national identity.
President Trump's vision to rehabilitate the Gaza Strip faced widespread opposition by the international community and all the countries of the Middle East, with the exception of Israel, in addition to the refusal of the Palestinians. Trump's vision is based on the idea of ??transporting two million Palestinians living in the sector to other countries, specifically Egypt and the neighboring Jordan, although media reports also reported farther destinations such as Morocco, the Somalia and Puntland. On February 4, last, the US President said: "I hope we can do something good that does not make them want to return again," while members of his administration described the evacuation of the Palestinians as a "temporary" or "phased" arrangement, and the United States will do yet This is to supervise the rehabilitation project, while other countries will be funded. Gaza is supposed to turn into "Riviera Middle East" where people from all over the world can settle in it, while "the Palestinians will be resettled in safer societies. And beautiful.
In response, both the Palestinian Authority and the Hamas movement - despite their bitter differences on other issues - announced that they will not accept any arrangement that contradicts the Palestinian "right", which reflects the spirit of steadfastness that has long prevailed in Palestinian society. The Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas described the plan as a "serious violation of international law" and was quick to coordinate with Egypt, Jordan, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates to develop a common position. The Hamas movement confirmed that it will not allow "ethnic cleansing" and forced displacement of the Palestinians from Gaza, where the prominent member of the movement, Ezzat Al -Rashr, said: "The plan reflects a deep ignorance of Palestine and the region, Gaza is not a real estate sold and bought, and it is an integral part of our occupied Palestinian land ".
Likewise, the Palestinian public received Trump's declaration with mixed feelings of amazement, anger and frustration. The vast majority of commentators rejected this proposal categorically, and considered it another example of Israel's intention to manage a new catastrophe, as happened during the war, in reference to the term "Nakba" that is used to describe the displacement operations that the Palestinians were subjected to during the founding of the State of Israel. A comment to one of the guests, who was conveyed in the media, embodies the size of the general feeling there, as she said: "We are not an abandoned building that anyone can claim it. We are a people. We belong to this land." Others sarcastically asked why Trump did not offer the United States as a Palestinian immigration destination. Likewise, Palestinian social media users expressed their dissatisfaction with what they consider an American -Israeli conspiracy to erase their national identity. Many commentators describe the current situation of the Palestinian National Movement as witnessing a significant decline, as it suffers from internal disintegration and weakness and relies heavily on external support to thwart the Trump plan. They also indicated that the movement failed to mobilize widespread popular resistance against the plan. However, some isolated voices appeared between the Palestinians that welcomed the idea of ??Trump, considering it a possible opportunity for a better future for them and their children.
Trump's proposal - which consists of a group of general principles more than being a detailed plan - reflects his primary approach in dealing with political affairs. As a businessman, he looks at individuals as economic creatures that give priority to personal gains The concrete - like the prosperity from which they derive their dignity - are on the abstract collective goals such as national independence and cultural or religious identity. This perspective is also embodied in its proposals related to Greenland, Canada and the Panama channel, where the political concept of "sovereignty" is replaced by the term "ownership" the "economic" and deals with the lands as if it were real estate for sale and purchase.
According to this point of view, providing material advantages to the Palestinians to urge them to abandon their national novel is an attempt to enhance the so -called "economic peace". However, this approach can only be achieved between sovereign countries, as none of them is required to abandon basic elements of their identity in exchange for economic gains. A prominent example of this is the "Abraham" agreements, the peak of the Trump administration's foreign policy achievements during his previous presidency.
Immigration policies in the past
The idea of ??settling the conflict by stimulating the immigration of Palestinians from the Gaza Strip is not a new idea. In fact, it formed a pivotal element in the Israeli strategy after the occupation of 1967. The signs of this approach appeared early in the occupation. Israeli in the period 1956-1957. In recent years, politicians from the Israeli right -wing current have made similar visions, whether before the outbreak of the current war or in its wake. A study conducted by the researcher Omari Shafir Rafiev, who specialized in studying Israeli policy towards the Palestinians after the Six -Day War, revealed that Israel worked to strengthen initiatives aimed at encouraging the immigration of the Palestinians (actually transferring them) to destinations outside its control, especially Latin America and the Arab Gulf states. Israel also studied scenarios for resettlement of Gaza residents in areas under its control, such as the West Bank, and previously in Sinai.
These policies aimed at the beginning to push the people of Gaza to leave completely, or at least to push a large part of them to leave. However, the failure of these efforts, in addition to internal political discussions - where some questioned whether to reduce the population of Gaza deserves to increase the number of Palestinians in the West Bank - prompted Israel to change its focus and encourage the migration of specific groups of Gaza population. In particular, this included individuals who were classified as extremists or considered a security threat source, especially educated youth. Israel has sought to achieve this goal by reducing appropriate job opportunities in Gaza.
On the ground, the policies specifically designed to encourage the emigration of the Palestinians only performed to leave a very limited number of people. The broader political measures such as opening the border had a greater impact - by 1987, more than 94,000 Gaza population left (nearly A quarter of the residents of the sector in 1967) through "calm and spontaneous" migration. Recently, several international organizations reported that between 250,000-350,000 Palestinians left Gaza during the period of Hamas's control of the Strip in 2007 to October 2023. Between 115,000-135,000 other people left between the October 7 attack and the closure of the Rafah crossing in May 2024. According to the results of the survey by the Arab Barometer on September 2023, nearly a third of the Gaza population is five and five. Residents of the West Bank are considering immigration for economic, political, or security reasons, or is linked to the rule. Canada, the United States and Qatar.
Arab concerns
From the point of view of the Arab countries, Trump's plan lacked two fundamental elements: The first: ensuring that part of the Palestinians remain at least in Gaza to prove that the rehabilitation process is possible even with the population survival; The second is to include the process within a political path, even if it is long -term, which ultimately leads to the establishment of a Palestinian state. These countries will seek to show their willingness to contribute effectively by providing financial aid, equipment, consultants and engineering plans, and even the formation of a joint Arab security or civil force in Gaza - a step that has not yet been implemented. These countries also count that this contributes to Trump's pregnancy to give up his plan, especially since the American administration has announced its openness to better alternatives.
At the same time, Qatar and Turkey are making efforts to integrate "Hamas" into the institutions of the Palestine Liberation Organization. However, due to the lack of a direct dialogue between "Fatah" (the faction controlling the Palestine Liberation Organization) and "Hamas", it is unlikely that they can reach a detailed agreement. Instead, both chapters may propose to form a general framework, such as the establishment of a committee Civil affiliated with institutions The Palestine Liberation Organization, in the hope that the Trump administration will see a sufficient measure, at least at the beginning.
conclusion
Trump's vision of the immigration of the Palestinians from Gaza and turns the region to "Riviera" on the basis of a pragmatic economic logic, as some Palestinians may migrate if the circumstances are favorable - for example, if they have the necessary means to leave, and if there are welcoming and developed destinations. Group immigration remains as part of an official political plan - especially those that prevent their return - is excluded. Ultimately, the spirit of steadfastness remains a fundamental component of the Palestinian national identity, and without it, the Palestinian national movement will lose its justification.
It should be noted that Trump's vision arises in the context of the vacuum resulting from the absence of a clear and applicable Israeli plan for the "next day" in Gaza. If Israel succeeds in formulating such a plan, it will be able to form the situation "from the river to the sea", while it opens the way to strengthen relations with Arab countries.

The statements of US President Donald Trump about the displacement of Palestinians from the Gaza Strip to Egypt and Jordan are raising a wave of controversy and anxiety, in light of warnings that they carry deep political and strategic dimensions, reflecting the Trump administration’s directions, so does these statements come within the framework of a greater plan that aims to liquidate the issue Palestinian by imposing a new reality by force? Or is it just an attempt to explore international and regional reactions?
Political and specialized writers and analysts believe And university professors, in separate conversations of "?", that Trump's statements are not random, but may reflect a systematic policy aimed at changing the demographic map of the region, since the first day of his inauguration, Trump has talked about Gaza as an economic and investment project, not as a human and political issue, and this vision corresponds to With the extremist Israeli right plans, in preparation for the implementation of the "Greater Israel" project.
They confirm that Egypt categorically rejects any projects aimed at resettlement of the Palestinians on its soil, while Jordan faces great sensitivity to the issue of resettlement due to the presence of a large number of Palestinian refugees on its lands.
They see that the Palestinian people, who have survived the extermination and ethnic cleansing, will not give in to the threats of displacement, as the Palestinian issue is the issue of existence and identity, it will not be abandoned easily and will remain alive and no one will be able to liquidate it.

Trends rooted in the principles of Zionist Christianity

The professor of political media at Hebron University, Dr. Saeed Shaheen, confirms that the statements of US President Donald Trump regarding the Palestinian-Israeli conflict reveal his directions rooted in the principles of Zionist Christianity, which he clearly adopts.
Shaheen believes that these principles constitute the basis for behavior Trump, the politician, noting that everything that comes from it reflects the trends of the far -right, the extremist, and serves the demands of the biblical Zionism aimed at displacing the Palestinians, taking advantage of the state of Palestinian division and Arab dependency on the United States.
Shaheen believes that Trump's recent statements about the displacement of Palestinians to Jordan and Egypt come in the context of completing the projects that he failed to achieve during his first term, foremost of which is the acceleration of the pace of normalization between Israel and Arab countries through the Abrahamic agreements.
Shaheen notes that the ultimate goal of these projects is to fully liquidate the Palestinian issue, by strengthening normalization and swallowing more Palestinian and Arab lands.
These plans also aim, according to Shaheen, to implement the vision of the extreme Israeli right, represented by figures such as Bastel Smotrich and Etamar bin Ghafir, who seeks to empty the West Bank, Gaza Strip and Jerusalem from the Palestinians, in addition to the displacement of Palestinians inside, stressing that these policies seek to change the balance The demographic, which tends to be in favor of the Palestinians.
In a related context, Shaheen warns that these statements may threaten the sovereignty of Arab countries like Jordan And Egypt, noting that Trump's application is identified with the aspirations of the extremist Israeli right may lead to tense relations with these two countries, and perhaps fully blown them, stressing that the matter depends on the ability of Jordan and Egypt to face and thwart these plans.
Shaheen notes that these statements may be an opportunity for the Palestinian situation to achieve national unity, stressing that facing these crazy plans requires ending the Palestinian division and enhancing cohesion between different parties.
Shaheen praises the role of regional and international initiatives, such as the outputs of the Moscow, Algeria and Beijing meetings, in promoting Palestinian reconciliation, stressing that the success of the Palestinians in addressing these policies will be largely dependent on their ability to overcome their differences and unite their ranks.
Shaheen stresses that the American administration, in light of its regionally and internationally influence, is a dangerous tool in implementing the plans to liquidate the Palestinian issue.
Shaheen stresses that facing these policies requires a collective move from Arab and Islamic countries, in addition to the cohesion of the Palestinian ranks, to address any attempts aimed at undermining Palestinian rights and robbing more lands.

Repercussions Dangerous for Trump's statements

The writer and political analyst Mohamed Gouda warns of the serious repercussions of US President Donald Trump's statements, in which he called for the displacement of Palestinians from the Gaza Strip to Egypt and Jordan, stressing that these statements are not just a slip of tongue or passing statements, but rather a systematic policy aimed at changing the geographical and political reality In the region, and to complete the project that Trump started during his first term under the name "Deal of the Century".
Joudeh notes that Trump's statements come within the framework of a larger plan that aims to liquidate the Palestinian issue, by imposing a new reality by force, and re -drawing the demographic map of the region.
"Trump from the first day of his inauguration spoke about Gaza, its geographical location and its beautiful sea, as if he was looking at it as an economic and investment project, and not as a humanitarian and political issue," says Gouda.
Jouda confirms that these statements reveal serious orientations that have been previously disclosed through the "Wickkes" leaks, where US Vice President GD Verse spoke about a project to impose an American mandate on Gaza for 100 years, similar to the situation that Hong Kong was under British rule. ”
The quality confirms that such plans aim to Weakening the Palestinian presence, dropping the project of the Palestinian state, and ending the Palestinian issue completely.
On Egypt and Jordan's position on these statements, Gouda confirms that Cairo considers itself a guarantor of regional stability, and categorically rejects any projects aimed at resettlement of the Palestinians on its territory, whether in Sinai or others.
"Egypt always confirms its support for the two -state solution, and rejects any plans that threaten its national security or change the demographic map in the region."
"Such statements may lead to tense relations between Cairo and Washington, especially if Egypt feels American pressure in this direction."
As for Jordan, Jouda indicates that Jordan is facing great sensitivity to the issue of resettlement, in which a large number of Palestinian refugees live, and Jordan rejects any steps that add a new burden on it, and this may lead it to take a strict position towards the United States.
"King Abdullah II repeats his rejection of such solutions that exceed the national rights of the Palestinian people, and I expect that US sanctions will be imposed on Jordan as a result of his rejection of Trump's calls."
The quality explains that Trump's statements aim to continue policies Liquidation of the Palestinian issue, by marginalizing the rights of the Palestinians to return, self -determination and establish the state.
"These statements strengthen the Palestinian feeling of no confidence in the international community, and ignite more anger towards American policies, especially after previous decisions such as moving the American embassy to Jerusalem," says Gouda.
Joudeh believes that such statements may lead to rearranging regional alliances, as the affected countries are converging of these ideas, such as Egypt and Jordan, to address them, as they will weaken calm efforts in Gaza, and may push to a greater escalation in the region as a result of the popular anger and resistance to these projects .
It calls for the unity of the Arab position, especially from Egypt and Jordan, to confront these plans targeting the Palestinian presence.
"A solid and solid Arab position is required to confront these dangerous statements, which aim to completely end the Palestinian issue," says Gouda.
The quality of the necessity of a unified and constant Palestinian position rejects any form of displacement, and emphasizes the right of the Palestinians to their land and homeland.
Joudeh stresses that the time has come to pressure by the international community on Israel, to recognize the Palestinian presence on this land, and on the right Establishing the Palestinian state on the borders of June 4, 1967, with Jerusalem as its capital.
"Israel must be obligated to implement all the laws and treaties approved by international legitimacy, which recognize the rights of the Palestinian people and their just cause, foremost of which is its right to self -determination and national independence."
Gouda warns that Trump's statements, if they are not met with decisive responses from Egypt, Jordan and the international community, may lead to undermining efforts to bring peace, and the humanitarian and political situation in Palestine and the region as a whole.
Gouda confirms that the next with Trump will be worse, and will work to impose a new reality by force, which requires firm positions on all parties concerned.

A type of "political fascism"

The writer and political analyst Sri Samour confirms that the recent statements of US President Donald Trump about the demand of Jordan and Egypt to receive the Palestinians can be considered a kind of "political fascism", indicating that they may not necessarily express an actual plan, but rather may aim to explore various reactions and test possible solutions To serve Israeli interests.
Samour explains that the primary goal of these statements is to push the parties The various, especially the Palestinians, to submit proposals that would mainly satisfy Israel.
"Trump sees himself more Israeli than the Israelis, and places the interest of Israel above all considerations, which is reflected in the nature of his proposal to deal with the region," says Samour.
Samour notes that the absence of clear plans or complete perceptions of post -statements is the prominent feature of these proposals.
Samour believes that "even Israel itself lacks a clear perception of the next day, which appears in its previous failures, whether at the level of suggestions or procedures, such as staying in Natsarim, but Israel was forced to withdraw from it."
Samour affirms the danger of using the reconstruction file as a pressure card and political extortion against the Palestinians, warning that the reconstruction of Gaza will be linked to conditions that harm the Palestinian national identity and resistance, and even to the entire Palestinian presence.
"This point specifically represents a great future threat, as Gaza's need for reconstruction can be used to force the Palestinians to accept plans aimed at undermining their national rights," said Samour.
On the impact of Trump's statements on American relations with the countries of the region, such as Egypt and Jordan, Samour confirms that the two countries are receiving Great American aid, making them vulnerable to Washington's pressure and extortion.
"It is not possible to predict how Egypt and Jordan respond to these proposals, especially in light of the continued American pressure," says Samour.
Nevertheless, Samour stresses that the real bet in facing these plans should be on the Palestinian people, specifically the people of Gaza, who are supposed to reject any attempts to pass these plans.
He says: "Trump's statements, if they were implemented, are a clear threat to the Palestinian presence, and they are not limited to Gaza only, but may extend to the West Bank."
Samour believes that these statements were supposed to pose a motivation to unify the Palestinians in the face of common threats, but it expresses his regret that there is no unified national strategy so far.
"Despite the bleeding blood in Gaza, we have not yet seen a joint national program to confront what is going on," says Samour. We hope that Trump's statements will pose a alarm that motivates everyone to join hands and develop a unified national plan, but unfortunately the indicators do not suggest this. "

A project compatible between the Trump administration and the occupation government

The researcher specializing in Israeli affairs and conflict issues warns Nizar Nazzal of the seriousness of the US President's statements Donald Trump regarding the displacement of Palestinians from the Gaza Strip and the West Bank, stressing that it is not just random statements but rather reflects an integrated project that has been agreed upon between the American administration led by Trump and the ruling class in Israel, led by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
Nazzal explains that Trump's statements regarding the displacement of the people of the Gaza Strip to the Sinai or Jordan are part of a major political plan that seeks to liquidate the Palestinian issue by forcibly displacing the population.
Nazzal notes that these statements are in harmony with the aspirations of the Israeli extremist right, which seeks to keep the historical geography of Palestine free of the Palestinians for the benefit of the Israelis, considering that Trump provides the "Great Gift" of Netanyahu in this context.
Nazzal believes that Trump, known for his nature as a businessman and coming from the heart of capitalism, deals with the Palestinian issue with the logic of deals, believing that the solution to the issue can only take place through the complete displacement of the Palestinians and granting Israel full control over the historical Palestinian territories.
Nazzal confirms that these ideas are not new, but rather an extension of previous projects such as "the deal of the century", which talked about residence An isolated Palestinian entity in Sinai.
Regarding the people of the Gaza Strip, Nazzal explains that Trump's statements indicate an American-Israeli consensus on the displacement of the Strip residents as a first step, in preparation for the move to talk about the displacement of the people of the West Bank.
Nazzal notes that this trend reflects an integrated plan to empty the sector of its people, invoking the reconstruction of Gaza or finding temporary solutions, while the real goal is to implement the forced displacement project.
And he confirms that this plan constitutes a great demographic threat to neighboring countries, especially Jordan, which currently includes a large percentage of the population of Palestinian descent, reaching 70 percent.
Nazzal explains that the displacement of more Palestinians to Jordan will significantly affect the demographic balance inside the Kingdom, which is a threat to its stability.
As for Egypt, Nazzal believes that the Egyptian state will stand with full force against this project, given the threat of Egyptian national and strategic security, stressing that Egypt, with its strong army and its accumulated diplomatic expertise, is able to address any attempts aimed at its security, indicating that Egypt will not allow the establishment of A Palestinian entity isolated on its soil in Sinai.
And in Concerning relations between the United States and the Arab countries, Nazzal explains that Trump's statements may lead to diplomatic drought between Washington and Egypt, but it is unlikely to reach the level of estrangement. As for Jordan, the relationship between the two countries will remain, given the size of their common interests, on Although limited tensions can occur.
Nazzal notes that Trump's statements coincide with his efforts to normalize relations between Israel and the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, which reflects an American-Israeli desire to provide assurances to the Saudi side regarding the solution of the Palestinian issue that the displacement will be temporary until the reconstruction is completed, even if it was at the expense of Palestinian rights.
Nazzal believes that Trump's statements are not only related to the Gaza Strip, but also touched on the inhabitants of the West Bank, where he spoke about Jordan clearly, indicating the intention to expand the circle of displacement in the future.
On the Palestinian level, Nazzal notes that Trump's statements reflect a threat to the Palestinian people, which calls for a comprehensive alert to confront it.
Nazzal confirms that the Palestinians categorically reject any plans aimed at forcibly displacing them, noting that the gradual return of the displaced to the north of the sector Gaza, despite the circumstances of extermination, reflects the will of the Palestinians to adhere to their land and refuse to get out of it.
Nazzal stresses that the Palestinian people realize that this displacement project represents an existential threat to them, whether in Gaza or the West Bank, and that confronting these plans requires a national cohesion and a unified position, indicating that the current Palestinian division constitutes a major obstacle to facing these challenges.
Nazzal confirms that the Palestinians are facing a real and serious danger that requires a comprehensive movement to confront it, calling for unifying Palestinian efforts and working to thwart these plans aimed at liquidating the Palestinian issue.
Nazzal notes that the coming years will be very difficult for the Palestinians, in light of the presence of a biased American administration that seeks to impose radical solutions to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, ignoring the national and historical rights of the Palestinian people.

Egyptian Foreign Minister Badr Abdel -Ati expressed his country's aspiration to work with the new American administration to achieve security, stability, just and comprehensive peace in the region.
This came during the meeting held by the Egyptian Foreign Minister Badr Abdel -Ati in a discussion session with his American counterpart Marco Rubio at the headquarters of the US State Department in Washington in the first official meeting between Cairo and Washington after Trump's statements.
The meeting between the Egyptian Foreign Minister and his American counterpart dealt with the overall bilateral relations between the two countries, ways to enhance the four -year strategic partnership, and support cooperation in various fields in order to achieve common interests.
Abdel -Ati stressed to his American counterpart the principles of the Egyptian, Arab and Islamic position on the Palestinian issue and the importance of achieving the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people.
Abdel -Ati expressed Egypt's aspiration to coordinate with the American administration in order to work to achieve the desired just peace in the Middle East, in a way that responds to the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people, on top of which is its right to establish an independent state on all its national soil.
Abdel -Ati reviewed Egypt's efforts to implement the ceasefire agreement In all its three stages and the enforcement of humanitarian aid, stressing the importance of expediting the start of the process of early recovery, the removal of the rubble and the reconstruction of the presence of the Palestinians in Gaza in light of their adherence to their land and their complete rejection of displacement with full support from the Arab and Islamic worlds and the international community.
The Egyptian Foreign Minister stressed the importance of finding a political horizon that leads to a final settlement of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict in accordance with international legitimacy resolutions, in a manner that ensures the establishment of an independent Palestinian state on the lines of June 4, 1967 with East Jerusalem as its capital to achieve security and stability in the Middle East region.
The Egyptian Foreign Ministry spokesman confirmed that the meeting witnessed an extensive discussion between the two ministers on the successive regional developments in Gaza, Syria, Libya, Sudan, the African century and the Red Sea.
On the situation in Sudan, the Egyptian Foreign Minister stressed the position of Egypt in support of the Sudanese state institutions, the need to stop the shooting, and respect the sovereignty, unity and integrity of Sudanese lands.
The talks also dealt with developments in Syria, emphasizing Egypt's full support for the Syrian people and the need to respect the unity and integrity of the Syrian lands, and the importance of starting a political process. Do not exclude any components of Syrian society and that Damascus is a source of stability in the region.
The talks between the two ministers touched on the issue of the Egyptian water security, as the Egyptian Foreign Minister stressed his country's fixed position on the necessity of reaching a legal and obligated agreement to operate the dam and without the disturbances on the rights of the estuary states and achieve the common interests of all parties.
The talks also witnessed the exchange of visions on a number of other issues of common concern, including developments in Lebanon, Libya, the African century and navigation security in the Red Sea, and it was agreed on the need to continue consultation and coordination between Egypt and the United States.

But this summit comes at a very difficult time for Egypt, as Cairo faces unprecedented challenges at the level of national security. In addition to African crises, the summit coincides with the war in Gaza, which constitutes a direct threat to the stability of the region, especially with its repercussions on Egyptian security. The American administration's plan to displace the Palestinians, according to US President Donald Trump's proposals, is raising existential concerns for Egypt, threatening to create a new reality that may lead to the reshaping of population and geographical balances in the entire region. This places Egyptian diplomacy in front of a double challenge to face international pressure on this issue, and at the same time, maintaining its strong presence within the African Union.

The Horn of Africa is witnessing an escalation in tensions, especially between Somalia, Ethiopia and Eritrea, after Ethiopia signed an agreement with Somalia Land (Somaliland region), in March 2024, granting it a marine outlet across a port on the sea Red, in exchange for recognition of the region, which sparked angry reactions from Mogadishu. This move may cause transformations in the balance of power in the region, which requires an active diplomacy to protect stability and enhance its historical relations with the countries of the region. Through the current summit, Cairo can push towards a political framework that guarantees respect for the national sovereignty of African countries, and prevents conflicts from escalation.

During the summit, Cairo pushed a comprehensive political solution that restores stability to Sudan

As for Sudan, it is a major strategic importance for Egypt, but the continuation of the conflict between the Sudanese army and the rapid support forces enhances instability and threatens the unity of the Sudanese state. With the exacerbation of the humanitarian situation and the displacement of millions, Egypt continues its diplomatic efforts to contain the conflict through international and regional mediation. According to information available to Al -Arabi Al -Jadeed, Cairo pushed during the African summit to find a comprehensive political solution that restores stability to Sudan and preserves its land unit, by communicating with all relevant parties. The Ethiopian Renaissance Dam file is a constant concern for Egypt, as Addis Ababa continues its unilateral policy regarding filling And the operation of the dam without a binding legal agreement, which was also present in the Egyptian talks in Addis Ababa. Besides, the Entebby Agreement (for the Nile River Basin countries was concluded in 2010) as one of the thorny files, as some Nile Basin countries seek to redistribute water shares in a way that may harm the interests of Egypt and Sudan. Egyptian diplomatic sources confirmed to Al -Arabi Al -Jadeed that the African summit came as an important platform that Cairo used to reaffirm its historical rights in the waters of the Nile, and demanding a fair African mechanism that guarantees not to harm the water interests of the affected countries.
