In the file of the African coast, which is witnessing its country, such as Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso, the influence of terrorist groups is growing amid repeated military coups, in light of the decline in the Western role in the region and the increase in Russian presence through the Wagner Group, the situation has become more complicated. This places Cairo In front of major challenges, you realize that the stability of the African coast is closely linked to its national security, so it works to support security and intelligence cooperation with African countries. According to the Egyptian sources, Cairo "played a pivotal role during the African Union summit in pushing towards a joint strategy to combat terrorism in the region." The Libyan crisis remains one of the most prominent issues that haunt Egypt, as the political division between the governments of Tripoli and Benghazi and international interventions remains any radical solutions. Cairo fears that the continued stalemate will lead to the return of violence and chaos, which may directly affect its national security. Egypt always calls for a Libyan-Libyan political solution that preserves the country's unity, and continues to support the Libyan national institutions. At the African Union summit in Addis Ababa, Cairo tried to enhance its efforts to achieve regional consensus on a road map that ends the Libyan crisis.

Leading role
At the level of the African Union Foundation itself, the new leadership elections for the Union Commission, which will take place during the summit, represent a real diplomatic test for Egypt, which always seeks to enhance its role within the Union and the active contribution to drafting the decisions The continent. During the past years, Cairo has provided great support for its candidates in the leadership positions of the Federation, which reflects its commitment to expanding its continental influence. With the intensification of competition in this session, Egypt was facing a major challenge in enhancing the chances of its candidate for the vice -president of the Commission (Hanan Morsi), in light of the competition of other candidates from North African countries, led by Algeria candidate Ambassador Salma Malika Haddadi, who was elected yesterday for the position. Cairo, through its intensive diplomatic movement, seeks to enhance its alliances within the African Union to ensure its active representation in continental institutions, which is a pivotal step in establishing its role as one of the main forces on the continent.

Alaa Farouk, Minister of Agriculture and Land Reclamation, received today, Hussein Abu Saddam, and Al -Nubi Abul -Al -Bayz, representatives of farmers and farmers in my tribal face, and reviewed with them the efforts made by the Ministry to support the farmers, whether through the guiding schools and veterinary convoys spread in all governorates of the Republic, which are implemented by the Agricultural Research Center, Desert Research, and the sector Agricultural counseling and the service and follow -up sector, as well as the General Authority for Services Veterinary and livestock institutes.

Algeria will be ready to normalize its relations with Israel "on the same day when a fully sovereign Palestinian state is establishing." Thus, the response of the Algerian President, Abdel Majid Taboun, to a question posed by the French newspaper Lubinion on this issue.
Taboun added that his predecessor, President Al -Shazly and President Bouteflika, had previously confirmed that "they had no problem with Israel. Our only understanding is the establishment of a Palestinian state."
Although the dialogue conducted by the newspaper with Taboun touched on many issues, such as the Western Sahara and relations with Tunisia, China, France and the United States, and others, most of the attention of the Arab media and Arab media pioneers focused on this statement.
Some of them saw that it was a confirmation of Algeria's steadfast position on the Palestinian issue, while others interpreted it as a transformation in the country's compass and linked it with changing regional and international conditions.
Taboun statement raised many interactions inside Algeria, where some opposition parties and personalities expressed their concern and their rejection of the idea of ??normalization permanently.
End proposed stories
How can this statement be read? Is it really a change in Algerian politics? gesticulate The significance of its timing? Is it already a hidden pressure that the country is exposed to or feels close to it?
Many Algerians have always echoed at the popular and political levels this slogan, which was launched by the late President Houari Boumediene (whose rule continued from 1965 to 1978) as an expression of the country's firm support for the Palestinian issue. The country received Palestinian factions on its soil, led by the Fatah movement, and embraced a number of Palestinian conferences, the most prominent of which was the one who concluded with the announcement of the PLO "Independence of the State of Palestine" in 1988. Algeria also helped the Palestinians economically by providing financial grants for them, and hosted the dialogue of the Palestinian factions 2022.
It is known that Algeria did not participate in what is known as the Abrahamic agreements signed by Israel, the UAE and Bahrain in 2020, and the President criticized what he described as "jogging" towards normalization, saying that he will not participate or bless it, and stressed that "the Palestinian issue remains a sacred issue."

Some were surprised and expressed concern about the statement of President Taboun, while Others said that it did not bring new because Algeria adopts, like other Arab countries, the peace initiative launched by the late Saudi monarch, King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz, in 2002, which aims to establish a Palestinian state on the 1967 borders, the return of refugees, and the withdrawal of Israel from the occupied Golan Heights in exchange for normalization Arab countries have relations with Israel.
Many of the pioneers of social media stopped when the President mentioned the word "Israel" that he usually referred to and the majority of Algerian politicians and media professionals in the term "occupied entity", which was repeated on the Algerian presidency page on Facebook when reviewing the most important thing in the interview conducted by the President With Lobinion.
But Dr. Radwan Bouheidel, a professor of Algerian international relations, says in statements to BBC Arabic that “the word Israel came in the question posed by the journalist, and it is impossible for a French journalist to ask a question in which he says the Zionist entity or the occupied entity. What will be in the future, and not currently, we cannot say to the future the Zionist entity if a Palestinian state is established, we do not recognize an important entity It was, but we may recognize Israel if a Palestinian state is full of rights under the United Nations on the 1967 borders, "adding that Algeria has a stable position and will not change, and" it will remain on the side of the Palestinian people until its state is on the 1967 borders and its capital is Al -Quds Al -Sharif. "
And Bouheidel notes that the President Taboun "used the word Israel in response to the journalist's statements and did not say the State of Israel, and this is a point that I think should be pointed out," adding that the presidency page "published what Lopinion published to promote the issue before it was completely published."
The Peace Society Movement, which is the largest Islamic parties in Algeria, issued a statement in which it expressed its "complete rejection of all settlement and normalization projects", and reminded the President Taboun that he had previously described it as "the rejected journey."
The former movement head of the movement, Abdel -Razzaq Maqri, wrote on his Facebook account: "When we hear Trump and his advisers talk about expanding the entity and then giving the Palestinians a small state after the displacement of a large part of the Palestinians, the talk of Arab rulers about normalization becomes a frightening and inception of a Palestinian state."
This was followed by the opposition left -wing Labor Party, in which it said that the party cannot "imagine any change in The official Algerian position regarding our central cause and therefore the fabricated entity. ”The statement stated that the two -state solution was“ confirmed that it is a trick and a mirage. .
Some commentators saw that Taboun's statement does not mean any change in the Algerian position, because it "put the knot in the saw" by talking about a incapacitated condition, as they put it, is the establishment of a full sovereign Palestinian state because Israel and its Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will never accept it.
"The President Taboun's statements are neither a retreat nor a change in Algeria's position on the Palestinian issue, but rather the exact opposite ... the President Taboun is well aware that the Israelis who refused to establish a Palestinian state for 75 years of full years will not allow this simply. I think the statement is what It is only an embarrassment for the international community, for those who escape towards normalization without real compensation in favor of the Palestinian issue ... I think it is a word addressed to the international community, not the people The Algerian, because the Algerians know their country's position on this issue. "
But there are those who expressed his rejection of the idea of ??normalization Absolutely, he warned that this may be "the beginning", citing social media platforms with previous statements by the leaders of Arab countries that printed their relations with Israel, in which they expressed their adherence to the establishment of a Palestinian state "East Jerusalem as its capital."
Professor Jonathan Hill, director of the Institute of Middle East Studies at the University of Kings College London, told BBC Arabic that he had a change in the position of the Algerian President.
"This shift in the dialect and the talk about preparing to recognize Israel (on the condition of the establishment of a Palestinian state) indicates a change. There were occasions in the past in which the government's position with the people's position was not consistent (for example supporting the coalition led by the United States against Saddam Hussein In the second Gulf War), but not with regard to Israel.

Many of those who refuse to declare Taboun or his conservatives have spoken of pressure from the countries that refuse to normalize with Israel to change their position.
For example, the statement of the Peace Society Movement pointed to pressure exerted by the allied countries with Israel, especially the United States, "to drag the steadfast countries, including Algeria, to the quagmire of normalization", and stressed the refusal of the movement For any pressure in this regard.
Some of them linked Taboun's statement and recent regional and international changes, such as the Gaza war, and what is known as the axis of the resistance fell in the wake of the Israeli assassination of Hezbollah leaders and the fall of Bashar al -Assad's regime in Syria.
One of the most prominent of these changes was also a second period for US President Donald Trump, the godfather of the Abrahamic agreements, who had recognized the sovereignty of Morocco on Western Sahara at the end of its first presidential term, following the declaration of Rabat, its approval to normalize relations with Israel. Added to this is the tense relations between Algeria and France, which in return has strengthened its relations with Morocco.
Algeria has recently sought to document its relations with Washington in the military, security and economic fields. For example, the country signed a memorandum of understanding for military cooperation with the US military leadership in Africa "Africom" days after President Trump was inaugurated, and on January 22, an agreement was signed with the American Chevron Energy Group to assess the capabilities of marine oil and gas resources in the country. For its part, the United States seeks to enhance its influence in Africa amid growing Chinese investments On the continent.
Professor Hill says, "The timing of the advertisement is important. It greatly suggests the feeling of the Algerian presidency about the harm that the country may be exposed to if the United States exerts pressure on it or increased its support for Morocco," said Professor Hill.
He adds: "What has changed? The greatest change is a president's arrival in power in the United States that tends much more to conclude deals, and is ready to practice the influence of the United States more publicly (as he did with Colombia and Mexico), not to mention that Algeria is now finding itself in isolation The largest in the West, amid France's efforts to conclude closer ties with Morocco. "
But Dr. Bouheidel has a different opinion, as he says that "it is wrong to read the statements of President Abdel Majid Taboun in the context of recent regional changes, especially Trump's arrival in the presidency ... and I also believe that what the president told the French newspaper has nothing to do with our very good relationship with the United States. And Trump has admitted the sovereignty of Morocco, which printed his relationship with Israel through his tweet. Fate, and we are talking about 2025 and we are not in the first term For Trump.
Perhaps the timing of talking about normalization has contributed to the angry reactions, as it comes after a war that lasted for more than a year in Gaza and resulted in the death of more than 46,000 Palestinians, most of them women and children, according to the Ministry of Health in the Strip, and Trump's talk about "cleansing the sector" and hosting Egypt and Jordan for its residents.
Observers believe that President Taboun’s statement regarding conditional normalization with Israel may be a maneuver in which he tries to hold the stick in the middle, as he seeks to adapt to the regionally and internationally changing geopolitical data, by noting that his country's refusal to establish relations with Israel is not at all, and at the time Himself reassures the internal public opinion that his country will not abandon the condition of establishing a "full sovereign" Palestinian state.
But Professor Hill predicts the possibility of the Algerian president's statement that no party.
“Although [the permit] represents a shift in the Algerian position, this shift does not amount to the extent of congruence with Morocco's approach to Israel. It is possible that the actions of Taboun will not satisfy any party - it is more than the Algerians can accept and less than what the United States wants - Then you may leave it in a weaker position. The professor of political science, Dr. Suhail Diab, believes that the emergency meeting that the Arab League called on the 27th of this month reflects a unified Arab position in the face of American-Israeli plans to re-draw the map of the Middle East to serve Israeli interests alone.

Diab explains that this step represents a fundamental shift in the positions of the Arab countries, especially the Saudi-Egyptian-Jordanian axis, which seeks to strengthen its role in the balance of regional powers, and reject any attempts aimed at displacing the Palestinian people or imposing unilateral solutions.

Diab believes that this articulated stage must express an Arab consensus on the rejection of any plan to displace the Palestinians or impose an "alternative homeland" in any of the Arab countries, as this is a direct threat to national security for each country separately, and the Arab national security in general.

Diab notes that the statements of US President Donald Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on this issue are an existential threat to the region, due to its repercussions on Arab national societies and the stability of existing political systems.

Diab notes that this development represents the beginning of the disintegration of the traditional strategic alliance between some Arab countries and the United States, as the Arab countries have begun to realize the importance of adopting a more independent foreign policy, by diversifying their international alliances and opening up to other forces such as China, Russia, and Iran, along with Reinforcement Cooperation with European countries to confront extremist American policies.

This shift is expected to lead to the emergence of new understandings between the Arab axis and two major axes in the region, namely Türkiye and Iran, with the aim of facing the common existential threats imposed by American and Israeli policies.

At the international level, Diab indicates that Trump's policies were not limited to the Middle East, but also extended to crises with many countries in the world, as these policies seek to destabilize economic, security and military stability globally, to undermining international institutions such as the United Nations and UNESCO, International Criminal Court.

Diab explains that Trump and Netanyahu are working to form a new global system based on extremist right -wing rule, seeking to impose a specific political and economic model on all countries.

Diab believes that the Arab position rejecting these plans intersects with the interests of many affected countries, which may open the door for new international alliances to confront these trends.

Diab emphasizes the importance of basic steps to confront the planning for the Palestinian displacement, to move immediately to block the road in front of these plans before it is too late.

It indicates The priority must be for the reunification of the Palestinian ranks by forming a temporary technocrat that includes all Palestinian factions, including the Palestinian Authority, the PLO, Hamas and Islamic Jihad.
Diab stresses the necessity of jointly reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, to ensure the stability of the internal situation and prevent any attempts to impose external solutions.

It calls for the crystallization of an Arab political project, and possibly wider Islamic, aimed at supporting the Palestinian issue at the international level, by pressuring international institutions and international legitimacy to recognize the rights of Palestinians and emphasize the two -state solution.

Diab indicates the need to work on building a broad international alliance that includes Arab countries, the Islamic world, the European Union, and Latin America, in addition to the countries affected by Trump's policies such as Canada and Mexico.

Diab confirms that international institutions, such as the United Nations and human rights organizations, can play a decisive role in this alliance to stop US-Israeli plans and restore balance to the international system.

Diab stresses that this moment represents a historical opportunity for the Arab world to rebuild its alliances and prove its role as a major actor In international politics, instead of being satisfied with the role of the recipient of decisions.

Diab confirms that these developments may lead to a fundamental change in the balance of global powers, which calls for new Arab strategies to face future challenges.

Yahya Ibrahim Hassan Al -Sinwar led Hamas after moving between several roles inside it.

A state of retreat, confusion and hesitation

The writer sees And the political analyst d. Ahmed Rafik Awad that US President Donald Trump's statement that he is "not in a hurry" to implement a plan to displace Palestinians from the Gaza Strip reflects a state of retreat, confusion and hesitation, and perhaps temporary abandonment of the idea, the proposal that Trump launched with "Jazaj, ignorance and stupidity" faced a wave of Strong reactions at international and regional levels, which led him to reconsider his plan, or at least the slowdown in its implementation.

Awad asserts that one of the main reasons behind Trump's retreat from the implementation of his plan at the present time is that the mass displacement of the Palestinians represents a flagrant violation of international law and humanitarian law, and it also contradicts the traditional American policies that were reluctantly dependent on the conflict administration instead of igniting it with displacement projects Collective, adopting such an idea means that the United States turns its back completely for everything that has been agreed upon internationally in relation to The Palestinian issue, which may harm its global position and relations with allied countries.

Awad believes that the mass displacement of the Palestinians is not only a humanitarian catastrophe, but rather that it harms Israel itself, as it harms its allies in the region. Awad Trump describes as a real estate and broker man in nature, and does not think about history, national identities, rights, and international laws, but rather he simply follows his interest wherever he finds it, so his statements do not mean that he has completely retracted the idea, but may search for a better opportunity to apply it in The future is as a businessman who used to On bargaining, barter and negotiation, and knows that there is a great political cost to implement his plan at this time, and therefore its decline may be merely a tactical maneuver until the appropriate conditions are created.

Awad notes that Trump's retreat from the displacement project is not abandoning it, but rather a temporary calm, with the aim of avoiding violent reactions and rearranging political papers, because the Israelis do not stop thinking about the displacement, but they postpone the implementation until the appropriate opportunity comes, and Tram, which reflects Israeli desires More than being an independent decision -maker, he may return again to this plan, if he sees that the conditions allow this in the future.

Atallah stresses that Trump is not the owner of the idea, but rather a translation of the Israeli desire and program. Regarding Trump's lack of urgency to implement the idea of ??displacement, Hamed believes that this is not a retreat from the idea, but rather a deliberate tactic to calm Arab and international reactions, while continuing to keep the idea in the discussion.

According to Hamed, Trump's advisory team, as well as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, is well aware that the previous Israeli policies that sought to displace the Palestinians in Gaza greatly failed to achieve this goal, and therefore, Trump's successive statements about the displacement aim to keep the discussion alive about This idea without giving it up.

Rahal notes that these statements were not limited to Gaza, but rather have affected other sovereignty and members of the United Nations, NATO and the European Union, which threatens international relations and fuels global tensions.

Rahal stresses that Trump's positions bring back to mind the approach followed by Nazi leader Adolf Hitler before World War II, when he was talking about the "vital field" and the occupation of states.

Rahal explains that the world does not want to repeat this scenario, as he realizes the risk of Trump's statements that may lead to the aggravation of international relations and the increased possibilities of widespread disputes, Even a new world war.

Al -Dabi asserts that the international community, including the United States' traditional allies, reject the unilateral approach that Trump is seeking to impose, especially in light of the rise of other powers such as China and Russia.

Regarding the Palestinian issue, Al -Damai explains that the international condemnation of Trump's statements on Gaza comes in the context of defending the two -state solution, and rejecting any policies or plans that lead to its undermining.

Al -Dambi stresses that these condemnation not only reflects support for the Palestinian issue, but also international fears that Trump's policies will destabilize the region, Including Israel itself as a liberal and pluralistic state.

Al -Dabi stresses that the international condemnation of Trump's statements about Gaza is not just diplomatic reactions, but rather reflects a true concern of extremist populist orientations that threaten the stability of the world and enhance conflicts instead of resolving them through dialogue and negotiation.

Political goals and deeper strategy

The writer and political analyst d. Ahmed Rafik Awad that, in light of the recent Israeli escalation in the Jenin camp, which witnessed the demolition of residential squares and widespread destruction, the possibility of expanding the "Arc of Fire" in the West Bank is very high.
Awad is due to the multiplicity and diversity of the goals of the current Israeli government, which is not limited to what you call "fighting terrorist structure" or cutting Iranian financing and influence, but rather goes beyond this into a deeper political and strategic goals.

Awad notes that the Israeli government seeks to achieve goals that exceed the advertiser, after Israel succeeded in imposing a ban on UNRWA, now aimed at hitting Palestinian camps, emptying them from their residents, and reshaping their geography, and this includes the demolition of homes, streets, and the expulsion of the population Partial or total, and these steps are not random, but rather are part of a broader strategy that aims to weaken existence Palestinian in these areas.

Awad believes that the Israeli Minister of War, Yisrael Katz, seeks to present himself as a strong and firm minister of war, which may lead him to invent new goals to keep the conflict burning, and these goals may not be real, but rather a way to satisfy the Israeli right and distract the public from issues The Interior, such as the potential Gaza Agreement.

Awad believes that the expansion of the arc of fire in the West Bank may be a substitute for the resumption of the war in the Gaza Strip, especially in light of a possible American rejection of a new escalation there, and that any normalization process with the Arab countries requires stopping the war in Gaza, which leads Israel to transform the focus of the conflict To the West Bank.

Awad notes that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seeks to keep the conflict burning to avoid the disintegration of his government and postpone trials and elections, and that the Israeli right wants to establish the inclusion of the West Bank in part or completely, and the current war serves this agenda.

And he confirms that the goals of the Israeli war are multiple and varied, including what is internal and some of them are external, inner, the government seeks to satisfy the public and the extreme right, and provide a political "bribe" by replacing the ceasefire in Gaza with a war in the West Bank, while externally, Israel aims To weaken, surround the Palestinian Authority, and drop the two -state solution.

Awad notes that Netanyahu wants to achieve an easy victory in the West Bank, in addition to the declared goals such as "uprooting terrorism" and drying Iranian financing, but the war Currently serve deeper and more complex goals.

In the face of this escalation, Awad believes that the Palestinian Authority should change its relationship with Israel, even if this requires radical steps.

Awad stresses the necessity of achieving a real national unity between Fatah and Hamas, to block the way for Israel, which plays on the Palestinian internal contradictions.

Awad stresses the importance of tireless work by the Palestinian Authority to besiege and stripped the occupation, in addition to forming Arab and international fronts to pressure Israel to stop its aggression.

And he confirms that the Arab role, especially the Saudi role, must be clear and decisive in rejecting normalization with Israel without stopping the war and settlement, and without achieving the Palestinian state on the minimum borders.

Awad believes that the international pressure, especially by the United States, is the key to the solution to stop this massacre in Gaza and the West Bank, calling on Saudi Arabia, as a major regional power, to pressure Washington to achieve this goal, so normalization with Israel must be conditional on stopping the aggression and achieving a fair peace for the people Palestinian.

Eliminate Palestinian camps

The writer and political analyst Firas Yaghi confirms that what the West Bank camps are witnessing, on top Jenin camp, from systematic demolitions and destruction of homes and infrastructure, falls within the framework of a new Israeli policy aimed at rearranging the security situation in the West Bank, especially in the post -seventh stage of October 2023.

Yaghi explains that this policy focuses on eliminating Palestinian camps, not only in Jenin, but in all parts of the West Bank, in an attempt to impose a new demographic and geographical reality that serves the interests of the occupation.

Yaghi notes that more than 100 homes in Jenin camp were fully destroyed in the context of these operations that exceed that they are mere military measures to be part of a strategic plan to gradually displace the residents of the camps, and this comes in parallel with Israeli decisions such as stopping the work of the Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees. (UNRWA) and the legislation issued by the Israeli Knesset that seeks to undermine the legal status of Palestinian refugees, what It shows a clear desire to dismantle the camps and displace their residents.

He believes that Israel is trying to reshape the geographical structure of the camps, pointing to what happened through the incision of wide roads inside and around the Jenin camp, with the aim of facilitating the operations of storming the camp at any time And reducing the population density inside it, which may lead to the displacement of the population voluntarily or forcibly.

According to Yyghi, this trend is linked to the auctions between the military and security leadership in Israel, where Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seeks to enhance his political position by making prominent concessions and roles of currents such as the religious Zionism led by Bamtalil Smotrich, who seeks to impose full Israeli sovereignty on the West Bank by 2025.

Yaghi notes that the Israeli army is trying to confirm its ability to impose security and control of the West Bank independently of any partnership with the Palestinian security forces, which reflects a trend towards undermining the role of the Palestinian Authority and systematically weakening it.

Yaghi notes that the Israeli military operations have expanded to include new areas such as the Al -Far'a camp, Sumoun and Tulkarm, in a move aimed at imposing comprehensive control on the West Bank and devoting an irreversible occupation.

Yaghi confirms that Israel views the West Bank from two main perspectives: the first is security, by virtue of its geographical proximity to the heart of Israel and its overlap with the major Israeli cities, and the second is religious, given that the West Bank contains religious sites Historically, Israel considers part of the "biblical symbols", and for this reason, Israel sees that the West Bank is more strategically important than the Gaza Strip.

Yaghi notes that the policy of "expanding the arc of fire" in the West Bank, which is currently adopted by Israel, is not just a security plan but part of a long -term strategy aimed at establishing a wide network of barriers and iron gates - exceeding 900 barriers - to restrict the movement of the Palestinians and push them towards Forced migration.

He believes that this restriction is part of the policy of "voluntary displacement" that Israel pursues to empty the land from its indigenous population.

Yaghi asserts that these practices come in the context of preparing for broader political plans, which include imposing a new reality on the ground even if the establishment of a future Palestinian state, Israel seeks to ensure full security control over this country, while undermining its actual sovereignty and denying it the ability to manage its internal affairs freely .

Yaghi stresses the need for the international and Arab community to move, especially the American administration, to pressure Israel to stop these policies.

Although US President Donald Trump is clearly seeking to serve Israel by escalating threats against the Palestinians, these policies may lead to unexpected results, ultimately in the interest of the Palestinian issue instead of weakening it. Instead of pushing the Palestinian threats to surrender or immigration, it leads to generating new ideas for resistance, enhancing internal unity, and revealing the true face of Israel before the world, which restores the Palestinian issue to the center of international interest.
The more threats targeting the Palestinian presence, the more Palestinians create new methods to confront the occupation. At each articulated stage, the Palestinians face challenges with unconventional methods, whether at the level of popular, military, or even legal and diplomatic resistance. For example, the long blockade of the Gaza Strip did not lead to the surrender of the population, but rather turned the Strip into a center for innovation in the means of defense and attack, despite all the restrictions imposed on it. The return marches that started in 2018 were another model to re -impose the issue of the right of return on the international agenda, after the Trump administration tried to undermine it by stopping support UNRWA and the transfer of the American embassy to Jerusalem.
The direct threat to the deportation of the Palestinians or the annexation of large parts of the West Bank, re -prioritization within the Palestinian ranks, where political differences retreat to the existential danger that threatens everyone. In previous crises, such as the first and second uprisings, repressive Israeli policies led to strengthening the unity between the Palestinians, and made the resistance of the occupation the maximum priority. Today, with the escalation of threats, calls for unifying the Palestinian ranks are increasing, whether between the factions or between the Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza and the lands of the occupied interior, because everyone realizes that the conflict is no longer only political, but has become a survival struggle.
At the international level, the Trump administration appears to provide an unintended service to the Palestinians, by revealing the true face of Israel in front of the world. For many years, Israel tried to present itself as a country looking for peace, but when the United States adopts a public speech that talks about the displacement of the Palestinians by force or the inclusion of their lands, Israel is losing the moral cover that was hiding behind it. These policies strengthen Palestinian positions in international institutions, and are pushing organizations such as nations United and the International Criminal Court to review the escalation of pressure on Israel, as happened when the Trump administration moved the American embassy to Jerusalem, which led to a wide international consensus against the decision and Washington isolated politically.
Parallel to this, Trump's policies contribute to returning the Palestinian issue to the global interface, after continuous attempts to marginalize it. In recent years, it seemed as if some Arab and Western countries were heading to normalize their relations with Israel, ignoring the Palestinian cause. But with the escalation of threats to displacement and annexation, governments and peoples have become an undeniable fact, which is that the Israeli danger not only threatens the Palestinians, but may lead to destabilizing the entire region. This reality pushes many parties to reconsider their positions, and reaffirm the centrality of the Palestinian issue.
In conclusion, it seems that Trump, who thinks he is practicing the utmost pressure on the Palestinians, ends inadvertently pushing them towards more cohesion and renewal in confrontation methods. If Trump's intention is to eliminate the Palestinian issue, his policies may completely achieve the opposite, as the Palestinians become more determined to Survival, and more able to impose their issue on the international scene, is supported by increasing internal unit and a global, renewed awareness of their rights.
Trump and return the initiative to the Palestinian people
Despite the attempts of US President Donald Trump to undermine the Palestinian being and weaken it politically and geographically, these pressures may lead to the opposite of what he seeks, as the initiative returns to the Palestinian people themselves, who has always proven their ability to adapt to the various stages and respond to challenges in innovative ways. Every time the major powers tried to impose solutions that detract from Palestinian rights, the response came from the Palestinian street itself, which managed to turn the equation and reformulate the political scene according to its priorities.
Throughout history, the Palestinian political leadership was not the main driver of the major stages of transformation. Rather, it was the popular action that identified the path and forced everyone to restore accounts. In the 1987 uprising, there was no central decision to ignite the confrontation, but it started from the street, and imposed itself on the Palestinian leaders and the whole world, which later led to a strategic change in the form of the conflict. In the second intifada in 2000, the popular response came to re -draw rules The game after it became clear that the political path did not achieve Palestinian aspirations. Today, as American -backed Israeli threats escalate, Palestinians find themselves in front of a similar moment, as the mass action becomes the main driver of the next stage.
Israel's attempts, with American support, to dismantle the Palestinian identity or undermine its components, may push the Palestinian people to develop new forms of resistance and adapt to the new reality. Just as the Palestinians succeeded in confronting the displacement in 1948 by adhering to the right to return despite the passage of decades, and they were also able to transform the siege imposed on Gaza into a motive to develop their capabilities, they are able to transform the current threats into an opportunity to enhance their political and field presence. The next stage may be the stage of "re -invention of resistance", where the mass action is integrated with technological creativity, legal and diplomatic pressure, which creates a new dynamic that is difficult for the occupation to confront.
As the challenges continue, the features of a new Palestinian stage are clear that exceeds the imposed political restrictions. The Palestinians have become more aware of the necessity of building their own tools away from regional and international accounts, than might It leads to the emergence of a new Palestinian situation capable of restoring the initiative. This continuous adaptation to the requirements of different stages is what made the Palestinian issue remain despite all attempts to end it, which will make her impose herself again on the scene, no matter how severe pressure and challenges are.
Netanyahu's policies and the return of the one -state option to the forefront
The trend in Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, which is to deepen the occupation and reject the two -state solution, may ultimately lead to completely counterproductive results of what he seeks. Instead of paving the way to perpetuate the Israeli hegemony and impose a new reality on the Palestinians, it restores to the forefront ideas that were in slumber, such as the cucumber of a single democratic state, which may become in the future the most logical alternative in light of the collapse of the two -state solution.
The two-state solution has always been the option that international efforts to resolve the Palestinian-Israeli conflict have been based. However, Netanyahu's policies, which are sometimes supported by the Trump administration, led to a systematic undermining this solution by expanding settlement, attempts to include parts of the West Bank, and dealing with the Palestinians as a people that can be overcome Or even displacement. With the erosion of the chances of the establishment of an independent Palestinian state due to settlement and the dismantling of Palestinian institutions, a completely different equation is highlighted, which is that Israel itself is pushing towards an option that it did not even want to discuss: the one state between the Palestinians and the Israelis.
Although Israel has always rejected this option for fear of losing its Jewish character, Netanyahu's policies make the two -state solution impossible, and thus imposes on future generations to face an existential question: if there are no two states, what is the alternative? Palestinians who find themselves trapped between occupation and settlement will start, urgent or later, in adopting a different discourse, calling for full equality within one country that extends from the sea to the river, which may become more attractive to international parties that support human rights and democracy.
Instead of leading Netanyahu a project that ends the Palestinian issue, in reality it will underestimate it from converting it from the issue of a national liberation to the issue of civil and political rights within one entity, which may be more dangerous to the Zionist project itself. If Israel continues to prevent the establishment of a Palestinian state, the Palestinians will find themselves in front of an option Demanding the rights of full citizenship, which threatens the demographic structure of Israel and undermines its foundations as a Jewish state.
Ultimately, the more Israel continues to close the horizon of the two -state solution, the more likely the conflict will turn into a battle for rights and equality in one country, which may impose a new reality on everyone.
